results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 3/8  Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
EMBRACING IMPERMANENCE                                                                                                     a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | FEB. 9th - MARCH 8th


7:00 - 8:30pm

Learn how to remain happy when change feels like a dark storm cloud blotting out the light in your life, when a great relationship turns ugly, or when you find yet another gray hair. Imagine feeling completely relaxed and happy in all of those situations and being able to accept whatever happens in life with patience and calm.

By meditating on impermanence we can learn to keep a balanced and peaceful heart, even though things don’t last. 

Feel free to drop-in to any or all of the meditation classes in this series! No need to pre-register. 

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis


Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
Next up is Peter Pan by Regis Loisel. Thanks to Story for turning me on to this.

We're reading the whole thing, which you can get in a single volume. It was originally serialized in six volumes, but there's an omnibus that covers everything.


The Bumf:

Before he became Peter Pan, before his arrival to Neverland, he was a boy fighting for survival. Born into the harsh Dickensian London suburbs, an alcoholic mother leaving him in an almost-orphan state, Peter’s only retreat from reality was the fantastical stories given to him by a friendly neighbour - allowing him to escape temporarily from the darkness of the adult world.


If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!


If you're running late, please post a comment on the page for this meetup; in order to get a table at the Friendly Toast, we need to tell them how many people we have, so if you aren't there and you don't let us know what's up, we may not have space for you!


For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!

The venue is the Friendly Toast, which is a very casual kinda place with plenty of room where we can easily be heard. Please note though, that it's best to bring cash - although supposedly their card minimum has been relaxed - perhaps even obliterated!
results.how_to_find_us: We gather on the couches in the front beforehand, and once we have a quorum we get a table -- usually one of the booths or the tables in the very back if it's a large group. Ask the staff if you can't find us!
results.name: Peter Pan by Regis Loisel

results.description:
Join Natural Dharma Fellowship and Phakchok Rinpoche, a primary lineage holder in the Nyingma and Taklung Kagyu Lineages, for an evening teaching in Harvard Square on the topic of compassion. Rinpoche will offer teachings on the nature of mind, and the method for accessing it—natural meditation—a practice of uncontrived presence. Teachings will be alternated with meditation practice sessions.


Kyabgön Phakchok Rinpoche was born in 1981 and is a lineage holder of the Profound Treasures of Chokgyur Lingpa from the Nyingma School of Early Translations and one of the throne-holders of the Riwoche Taklung Kagyu Lineage. Phakchok Rinpoche’s primary root gurus are his grandfather, the late Kyabje Tulku Urgyen Rinpoche, and late Kyabje Nyoshul Khen Rinpoche.

Rinpoche recently completed a curriculum of higher education in India at Dzongsar Shedra, and now teaches Buddhist practice and philosophy internationally.

Contact : [masked]

Teacher Profiles:  Kyabgön Phakchok Rinpoche's bio can be found  here .

results.description:
Speaker: Jonathan Worthington (via tape delay)


Abstract: "Performance has long been one of the blockers to greater adoption of Perl 6. The language is designed in expectation of a sufficiently smart optimizer, knowing that such things are possible - but setting quite a challenge for those of us working on Perl 6 implementation.

Following the "make it work, then make it fast" approach, we've done a lot of work over the years on getting many language features to work well in Rakudo. ... In this session I'll discuss how we've been improving Perl 6 performance by working at all levels of the implementation: optimizing built-ins, improving the Perl 6 optimizer's ability to simplify code, and building a powerful dynamic optimizer for MoarVM that uses runtime information about a program's typical behavior to cheapen attribute accesses, resolve dispatches, eliminate type checks, perform inlining, and much more. I'll also take a look at the MoarVM JIT project, and how that is helping.

Finally, I'll take stock of where we're at so far using latest benchmark results: what we can do about as well as Perl 5, where Perl 5 comes out faster, and where Rakudo Perl 6 comes out ahead."

About the speaker

Jonathan Worthington is MoarVM and Rakudo Perl 6 compiler architect. Co-founder of Edument in Czech Republic. Like cooking/eating Indian food, craft beer, and seeing the world.
results.how_to_find_us: http://boston.pm.org/MIT+Directions
results.name: Perl 6 Performance Advances

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.



Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
This is a free stand up comedy show Tuesday night in the back room of Iron Furnace in Quincy. (Formerly Stadium)


At 8pm this room is transformed into the coolest little independent comedy club around. Each week it gets a little harder to find a seat so come early and meet the comedians while guaranteeing your place in the room. 

Hosted by Shawn Carter. The show was recently featured in The Patriot Ledger.

If you are an aspiring comedian you can participate in our free writer's workshop at 6:30pm.


If you just want to check out the stand up comedy show, that starts at 8pm.


If you are more interested in viewing or participating in the comedy debate segment of the show come by at 10pm. There's something for everyone!

results.description:
Lets enjoy some coffee and learn about investing! Investing is a beautiful art that when done correctly can help lead to a much happier life with less financial worries if you save properly and invest with long term goals in mind. The purpose of this meetup group is for like minded beginning investors to talk about investing ideas and to learn how to invest. Lets learn about stocks, bonds, mutual funds, ETFs, etc and which stocks we think are hot and which are not. 

About me: I love learning about investing. I graduated from an Ivy league university and I have been obsessed with investments and what they can do for individuals over time. I can't wait to talk over coffee and make new friends that also want to learn about investments.

results.description:
Join us for a demonstration of the IBM Service Virtualization solutions and the interactive white board discussion of your organization can leverage Integration Testing to power leading technology initiatives, including Mobile, Cloud, Big Data & Analytics, and Social Business.   This event is limited to the first 20 RSVP's. 


Where: IBM

550 King Street, Littleton, MA 01460

When:  Wednesday March 9, 2016
Time:  9:00 AM - 2:00 PM
Room:  Executive Briefing Center


This interactive workshop will focus on a subset of the overall DevOps approach, specifically Continuous Integration/API Testing and the Shift Left methodology. Participants are encouraged to ask questions and discuss their own challenging use cases during the Q&A and white boarding session.

Event Highlights:

During the event we will:

•  Discuss how the approach to testing software is changing in the era of the API economy

•  Delve into API/Integration testing strategies and the benefits of service virtualization

•  Demonstrate the real life examples of setting up testing where the external API services are virtualized

•  Facilitate an interactive white board discussion of the participants’ real life use cases that can tremendously speed up development and testing while increasing your organization’s productivity

Who should attend?

Anyone interested in learning how to Continuous API/Integration Testing solutions

•  Architect and Developers

•  Quality Engineers and Managers

•  Agile Leader and Project Managers

•  Operations Engineers

Registration URL: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ibm-continuous-testing-and-service-virtualization-workshop-tickets-22557750840

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!! 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 


TALK with us FIRST !! 

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas 

Vegan Cooking Classes or 
                 Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food 
                    (using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 

* What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?
* Portion Control
* Bake...Don't Fry!
* Roasted Veggie Stackers
* No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream
* Avocados!!!
* Salad with Chipotle Hummus
* Simple Cilantro Chutney
* More $2 bags of Produce!
* Drink your greens!

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limitsWe have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

We get together in the Longwood Medical Area on Tuesday evenings for bilingual chat, but just a few blocks away is one of the world's finest art museums (and it also has a section on Sinology or China studies).

results.description:
The Harvard Libertarian Forum and Harvard Fuerza Latina are proud to sponsor Open Borders Day at Harvard University!


Open Borders Day is an event dedicated to discussing the pros and cons of liberalizing borders.


Speakers:


Professor Lant Pritchett is currently Professor of the Practice of International Development at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University.


Jeffrey Miron is a Senior Lecturer and Director of Undergraduate Studies in the Department of Economics at Harvard University, as well as a senior fellow at the Cato Institute.


Bryan Caplan is a Professor of Economics at George Mason University and blogger for EconLog. His first book, "The Myth of the Rational Voter", was named "the best political book of the year" by the New York Times.


Valerie Vande Panne is the Director of Communications at the Massachusetts Immigrant Refugee Advoacy (MIRA) Coalition. Valerie is also an award-winning independent journalist and has been featured on The Guardian[UK[, Salon and other publications.


Location: Fong Auditorium (Boylston Hall)


Schedule:


The event will begin promptly at 5 PM so please ensure you arrive on time.
Each speaker will have 20-30 minutes to discuss their views on why borders should be liberalized.


After our speakers are finished we will open it up to Q&A for further discussion. The Q&A will go from 6:30 - 7:00 PM.


From 7 PM - 7:30 PM we'll have an after-social filled with pizza, refreshments and discussions about the event.


The event shall end at 7:30 PM with a cleanup. Folks are invited to help the organizers with cleanup.


Thank you very much for everyone's enthusiasim and support!
results.name: Open Borders Day @ Harvard University

Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

All are welcome.

Charleene's Country Line Dance Lessons take place Wednesdays in Weymouth (OR Angela hosts the Tuesdays in Braintree) and she has a great team helping her teach the classes. Beginner lessons @ 6-7pm and Advanced lessons @ 7-8pm. This is a fun way to learn several country line dances with others and get in a nice workout. You'll then be able to join in the fun when you are out and see other people line dancing. 

What to Bring/Wear:

~Cowboy Boots (if you have them), boots or shoes w/ heels; no sneakers!

~Comfy Clothes (remember, you're dancing!)

Cost is $10 and I suggest bringing cash.

Please plan to arrive a few minutes early if this is your first time attending. This way you can pay at the register and we can get introduced before the fun starts.

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD; FYI - This happens weekly and they don't dance if the governor says to stay off the road.


Parking: Free and ample parking on-site.

results.description:
On Wednesday, March 9th starting at 6:00, the MobileTea meetup and MassTLC will present the 9th edition of MobileTea. This evening event consists of knowledge and networking for anyone interested in Test Driven Development for mobile developers from a general introduction to cutting practices for iOS, Android and mobile friendly API. 

Participation is “free as in beer” and consists of 5 keynote speakers interspersed with 4 networking sessions that include live DJ’d music and hors d'oeuvres.  

Presentations will vary from 20 to 40 minutes and are followed by 15 minutes of networking.  Be prepared for an informal atmosphere, great food and drink.  Bring your passion for all things development, we look forward to meeting you!

Performing live: Subway DJ @Subway_DJ   
Mixologist: Chris Allen (Red5 Pro)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Registrations open at 6:00 PM, the event starts at 6:30 PM.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Event Program:

Networking Session 1 - DJ Mix 1 - Food & Drink  

A Practical Guide To Succeeding with TDD [J. B. Rainsberger www.jbrains.ca]
I originally chose to learn and practice TDD because I made too many mistakes and wanted to find and fix them sooner, so I first thought of TDD as a testing technique for programmers. Later, after I got my mistakes under control, I noticed that testable code tended to be well-designed code, so I realized that TDD isn’t a testing technique, but rather an evolutionary design technique. Over the years, I noticed that practicing TDD didn’t just guide me towards better designs, but rather it guided me towards a better understanding of the design principles that I managed not to learn from textbooks. I stopped thinking of TDD as a design technique and began thinking of it as a really-learn-the-principles-of-good-design technique. I have taught TDD this way for over a decade and now thousands of programmers have developed their design skill as naturally as the way they learned to speak their native language.
Of course, TDD didn’t change; I did. And TDD wasn’t even the most important ingredient in my evolution as a programmer!
In this session, I will share a little about how and why I adopted TDD, how it has helped me, and why I continue to do it over 15 years later. After that, I want to take your questions about TDD: how, why, when… whatever! In the process, I’ll even get to show you what incremental delivery really means.

Please bring your deepest, toughest, most burning questions about TDD. We can talk about both code and people, so don’t limit yourself. Ask anything! (If you don’t ask enough questions, I’ll just talk more about whatever I want to talk about.)
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 40 minutes) 

Networking Session 2 - DJ Mix 3 - Food & Drink  

Unit Testing Node.js Middleware [Morris Singer @morrissinger]
Even for JavaScript software developers well-versed in Agile practices, using test-driven development in the development of Node.js-based webservers can be challenging. In this presentation, I identify solutions to some of the most significant challenges to using TDD to build middleware stacks, with a focus on Express and Koa.
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes) 

Contract Testing the Mobile Boundary [Stephen Vance] 
Dylan and Steve will talk about doing mobile API contract testing with pact.(speech level: intermediate; duration: 25 minutes) 

Networking Session 3 - DJ Mix 3 - Food & Drink  


Validating network requests with a mock server [Matthew Patey]


For mobile developers, testing the product as a whole often means running tests in a UI automation framework. The application is treated as a black box in which all the inputs and outputs happen through the same interface with which the end user interacts. At Localytics, our mobile team develops client libraries that our customers integrate into their applications. The primary function of our client library is to package up information the application gives us and send it to our servers. For us, black box testing with the UI as our input and output is not very useful. Instead, our input is the application facing API, and our output is the network. To help us test our client library we have developed a mock server that lets us capture network requests and validate that they contain the correct data. This allows us to call into our client library and validate all outputs in an isolated testing environment. In this session I will discuss our need for the mock server, how it works, and other testing scenarios in which it may be useful.
(speech level: intermediate; duration: 20 minutes) 

Networking Session 4 - DJ Mix 4 - Food & Drink
results.name: Mobile Tea #9 + MassTLC: Test First or Die! (TFoD)

results.description:
Please join us at Laura’s Luscious Meals in Minutes. This will be a fun and interactive cooking and wine tasting event led by the dynamic Laura Hartung, RD and Nutritionist. Laura will show us how to create delicious and healthy meals in minutes, including a live cooking demo with delicious samples paired with wine. Tickets are just $20 and including the cooking demo, recipes to take home, the food samples and wine.


This is a multi-group event, and attendance is limited to 30 participants. Advance payment is required, which will cover the cost of food and wine. (You may pay through Eventbrite (total cost of $22.08 which include Eventbrite's fee https://www.eventbrite.com/e/lauras-luscious-meals-in-minutes-cooking-and-wine-tasting-event-tickets-21795465825), or pay Deanna through Venmo (total cost of $20 as Venmo does not charge a fee)).

Laura will show us how to stock our fridge and pantry with healthy and quick building blocks like kale, toasted pine nuts, canned beans and tomatoes, fresh garlic, bread crumbs, pecorino/parmesan cheeses, olive oil, spices, herbs, seeds and grains.

The menu for this evening will include Laura’s delicious Tuscan Kale Salad, Spicy Turkey Chili, and Fudgy Black Bean Brownies. At this special event, you will have the opportunity to form new friendships and also take home Laura’s luscious recipes that you will be able to make at home.

Laura has been a registered dietitian for over 23 years and is passionate about spreading the good word of health to the Boston, Cape and Metro West areas! Out in the corporate world educating the masses, she conducts interactive cooking/exercise demos and presents the latest research on how to eat to beat disease! Laura has recently counseled at Life is Good in Boston via Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, lead cooking demos at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institiute and headed employee exercise classes at Jorndan’s Furniture stites in three states! Laura rounded off the year conducting a healthy holiday appetizers cooking class at Sheply Bulfinch and nutrition seminars at Boston Financial Data Services. Laura loves to travel! She has visited both Greece and Italy, diving into their food culture while attending cooking workshops with other dietitians. She headed to Bali, Indonesia December 2015, for two weeks. Attending cooking classes, visiting organic farms and practicing yoga were among the few of her scheduled activities!

4 Longfellow Place is located off Stanford Street and a few blocks to North Station (Green, Orange and Commuter Rail) and Charles St/MGH stop on Red Line and Bowdoin on Blue Line. 

The parking garage is 60 Staniford St. (We will provide discount coupons at the event that will give a 50% discount off of parking.)
results.how_to_find_us: Meet us in the Lounge/Cooking area on the first floor. Call/text Deanna at 508-333-3191 to reserve your spot or for directions/more information.
results.name: Laura's Luscious Meals in Minutes! Cooking and Wine Tasting Event

results.description:
Autodesk will join us at BUG this month, showing how Unity developers can take advantage of web services for 3D asset scanning and viewing. They’ll show the ReCap API, a developer-oriented version of their 123d Catch software which creates 3D models from a series of photos, and also the View and Data API, a JavaScript viewer for all types of content. They’ll also tell us about Creative Market, their new asset marketplace.


The speaker is Kevin Vandecar, the API support manager for 3ds Max and Maya products under the Autodesk Developer Network. He is also presenting regularly on the forge.autodesk.com cloud service APIs from Autodesk.


And of course, there’ll be Autodesk (and Unity) swag!  Because there’s no such thing as too many free shirts, stickers, and pins.  


Also: bring your demos!  This isn’t a full-blown demo night, but feel free to bring what you’re working on, show it to BUG, and get some feedback!  And if you’re not coming with a demo, bring your playtesting cap, and be ready to check out some cool stuff and give your pointers!

Please RSVP so we can ensure enough food and drinks for the attendees! 


Our Sponsors:

Thanks to our sponsors! Unity and Akamai are generously sponsoring our meetup again this month.  

See you there!  

- B.U.G.
results.name: Bringing 3D Developer Tools to the Cloud with Autodesk (And Bring Your Demos!)

results.description:
Boston Traders' Meetup

You are invited to attend the monthly Boston Traders' Meetup meetings.

The format for the monthly meetings is that each person will introduce her- or himself and state the market that he or she trades and perhaps a very brief description of the approach taken. For example, an introduction could be, "Hi, my name is Fred Hampton and I trade forex breakouts during the London session."

From there, the floor is open for people to discuss anything about trading. You may talk about something you learned recently about trading or about an obstacle that you are facing in trading or make a request for resources from other members.

Please print out and bring this BostonTradersMeetup sign so you can connect with the other members easily.
www.meetup.com/BostonTraders/files/

Part of the purpose of this group is for people to connect with other traders so it's encouraged for people to exchange contact info. For example, if you are an options trader and another options trader talks about a topic that interests you, then feel free to ask the person if she or he would like to exchange contact info.

--------------------


This meeting is located in the Starbucks inside what is called the "Boston Marriott" even though the hotel is located in Kendall Square, Cambridge. The Kendall Square subway stop is a Red Line stop at "Kendall."

This meeting is FREE and it repeats on the 2nd Wednesday of every month.
results.name: Boston Traders' Meetup Group Meeting 2nd Wednesday at 6 PM in Cambridge

group.name: Boston Traders Meetup to Teach/Learn Trading Strategies

results.description:
Medicinal bark is harvested in late winter and early spring as the sap rises and before the plant breaks dormancy. Learn to distinguish trees and shrubs by their buds and bark. Trees can be identified year round mainly by bark and growth habits but the pattern of scales on leaf buds appearing in late winter are another excellent tool to help you spot your favorite tree for wildcrafting.

Identification is the skill set that will grant you access to free herbs! Witch hazel, willow, alder and oak, we'll discuss characteristic identifiers of each species and examine buds up close under a magnifying glass (feel free to bring one to class!).
Wednesday March 9th, 2016
6:00pm -8:00pm
549 Columbus Ave, Boston
the fee for this class is $20.

results.description:
The MFA is free* today!

Arrive any time after 4:00pm. Check your coats (also free) at one of the two coat rooms (I suggest the one near the Fens entrance, it is usually not as crowded as the Huntington coat room) and be on your own until 6:00pm, when we will MEET ON THE SECOND FLOOR UNDER THE ROTUNDA at the top of the main staircase from the Huntington entrance  - see floorplan.

Arriving early and need a rest? Relax in the leather chairs below the John Singer Sargent Murals as they extend towards the Huntington side of the building. Rest rooms are also available nearby.


The cultural exploring part?
Each participant willing to do so can play tour guide to some piece of art that is significant to their heritage. To prepare, review the MFA collection here. We'll (try to) stay together (those wishing to go off on their own are free to do so, but that kind of defeats the purpose of MeetUp). 

The museum closes at 9:45pm.

___
*Wednesday nights after 4:00pm, admission is by voluntary contribution (suggested donation $25). More info here.
results.how_to_find_us: 6pm - Meet under the rotunda on the second floor (see image).

results.description:
Hi everyone,

At our March meeting, our speaker will be discussing the testing role during a scrum... this will be an interactive session with lots of audience participation!

Hope to see you Wednesday @ 6pm!

-Steve-


Topic: Experience the Testing Role During a Scrum 

Speaker:  Mario Moreira, emergn

Meeting Date:Wednesday March 9 2016

Meeting Time: Networking 6-6:30pm     Discussion 6:30-8pm

Location:    Oracle Campus            

                     45 Network Drive Northwest Park                   

                     Burlington MA 01803

Cost:          Free! 

Abstract:   

In this interactive session, attendees will experience the Tester role on a Scrum Team simulating the activities during a Sprint. The simulation will exercise the elements of testing within the context of Sprint Planning, Daily Stand-up, Sprint Review, and Retrospective. Attendees will not only gain an understanding of Scrum, but will walk-away with hands-on experience of testing within a Scrum context.

Speaker Biography: 

 Mario Moreira is a VP of Client Engagement, Executive Consultant, and Master Agile Coach at Emergn focusing on business success by increasing value of products, optimizing flow for faster delivery, and increasing quality through customer feedback.  He has Scrum, XP, Kanban, and scaling Agile experience from team to enterprise-level agile transformations. Mario is an Agile industry leader and has authored Being Agile:  Your Roadmap to Successful Adoption, Adapting Configuration Management for Agile Teams, Software Configuration Management Implementation Roadmap, and Agile for Dummies.  He writes on his blog at Agile AdoptionRoadmap. You can follow Mario on Twitter at @AgileMario.
results.name: SQGNE March Monthly Meeting - Experience the Testing Role During a Scrum

Please click here to share/tweet our event with your network.


Each presenter gets 5 minutes for product demonstration and 5 minutes for Q&A.  Please follow @BostonNewTech and use the #BNT63 hashtag in social media posts: details here.


Brought to you by:

Foley Hoag LLP - No industry moves faster or makes a bigger impact on the way we live than the technology industry. Technology innovators in software, hardware, gaming, entertainment and telecom turn to Foley Hoag LLP to help secure and maintain their leadership positions in this competitive industry. Our attorneys provide a comprehensive array of legal services for companies in all stages of development, from conception through profitability and beyond. For more information, please click here to visit our website for technology entrepreneurs. Follow @FoleyHoag and like them on facebook. www.FoleyHoag.com [masked]

Mobinett Interactive specializes in strategy, design and development for mobile/web apps and backend software. Please contact us if you need any advice or help! Check out our "Top 10 Questions to Ask In Hiring a Mobile App Developer" and other helpful resources on the Mobinett Blog. Visit www.Mobinett.com, contact us here, or call <a>[masked]</a>. 


Products & Presenters:

1. Corto / @CortoProject - The app development platform for startups! (Sander Mertens / @Sander) Tech: C, C++, Python, JavaScript, mongoose, HTTP, DDP, MQTT, Meteor, mongodb. www.corto.io

2. Onshape / @Onshape - Full-cloud 3D CAD system using any web browser, phone, or tablet! (Mike LaFleche) www.Onshape.com

3. Spiro / @SpiroHQ - Combines user data, best practices and humor to help sales close more deals! (Adam Honig / @AdamHonig) Tech: iOS, Android, Heroku, Ruby on Rails, Angular, PostGres, Salesforce, Gmail, Exchange. www.SpiroHQ.com

4. Solaria Labs - Incubator develops new products and services with transformational potential! (Brigham Prescott) https://welcome.libertymutual.com/innovation/

5. DeepSQL / @DeepInfoSci - Adaptive MySQL database for intensive physical, virtual & cloud environments! (Mike Skubisz / @MSkubisz) www.DeepIS.com

6. Lexumo - Protecting the world’s open source software! (Brad Gaynor) Tech: Titan, Cassandra, ElasticSearch, Hadoop, Java, Python, Groovy, Bash, C, C++. www.Lexumo.com

7. Kx / @KxSystems - Column-based database with extensive in-memory and on-disk capabilities! (Jamie O'Mahoney) Tech: C. www.Kx.com

Agenda:


6:00 to 7:00 - Networking with dinner and drinks

7:00 to 7:10 - Announcements

7:10 to 8:30 - Presentations, Q&A

8:30 to 9:00 - More Networking

9:00 - More networking over drinks across the street, at The Whiskey Priest, 150 Northern Ave. (at Seaport Blvd.), Boston, MA. (optional)


Directions & Parking:


Foley Hoag is in the Seaport West building (entrance on B Street). Please bring identification and check in at our desk in the lobby. Type the last few letters of your last name on the screen or keyboard and once you see your name appear, tap on it to print your name tag. You'll also receive an access card to enter. Take an elevator to the 13th floor. Enter the glass doors and walk down the hall to your right.


Public Transportation:

Foley Hoag is in the Seaport West building, right next to the MBTA Silver line World Trade Center Station. Walk 1 block north on World Trade Center Ave and you will see the building on your left. You can also walk there in 15 minutes from the MBTA Red line South Station. 

Driving directions:

Use this https://maps.google.com/maps?ie%3DUTF8%26f%3Dd%26daddr%3DFoley%2BHoag%2BLLP,%2B155%2BSeaport%2BBlvd,%2BBoston,%2BMA%2B02210%26geocode%3DCZyPbW7oCbXSFWU1hgIdWfjD-yG1hpFfpE6UFg%26gl%3DUS%26hl%3Den">Google Map. There are parking meters along Congress St, Seaport Blvd, E Service Rd and Boston Wharf Rd and two open-air parking lots just east of the building (along E Service Rd), which charge $14-15 for the evening.

results.description:
Medicinal bark is harvested in late winter and early spring as the sap rises and before the plant breaks dormancy. Learn to distinguish trees and shrubs by their buds and bark. Trees can be identified year round mainly by bark and growth habits but the pattern of scales on leaf buds appearing in late winter are another excellent tool to help you spot your favorite tree for wildcrafting.

Identification is the skill set that will grant you access to free herbs! Witch hazel, willow, alder and oak, we'll discuss characteristic identifiers of each species and examine buds up close under a magnifying glass (feel free to bring one to class!).
Wednesday March 9th, 2016
6:00pm -8:00pm
549 Columbus Ave, Boston
the fee for this class is $20.
RSVP by emailing [masked] or by calling[masked]-0775. More information at www.growinghabits.com.
results.name: Winter Tree Bud Identification

results.description:
Let's have fun at Highball a Vintage Cocktail Lounge

Located inside  the  Nine-Zero  Hotel

With our collection of classic board and arcade games and comfortable chesterfield couches, it’s like you’re back in your childhood rec room again, only with way better tunes (thanks to our resident DJs) and much more grown-up libations.

Sip one of our craft cocktails while dominating your friends at Jenga, Candy Land or Pac-Man. Fun and festive, Highball Lounge is the kind of place where you might just find a tiny rubber ducky floating in your drink.

So come on out, toss your responsibilities away and kick back with a tasty beverage drink and good conversation. You know you want to.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

results.description:

Marie Aspling, founder of Balans Wellness Studio and Balans Organic Spa, is very kind to host the Boston Scandinavian Meetup on Tuesday, March 8th in Boston. 

Light h'orderves and some some scandinavian drinks will be served! (For free!)

6:30-7pm Mingle 

7-7:30/45 Presentation & discussion with questions from the audience 

8:00pm End

One other very interesting aspect of Balans Organic Spa is Maria Åkerberg Deerskin Organics, a leading organic Scandinavian skin and cosmetics brand with innovation and manufacturing in Sweden. Balans Organic Spa is the only venue carrying Maria Åkerberg in the North East!

What makes this white and pale wood oasis interesting are offerings that go beyond basic spa fare. In addition to an organic spa treatments Balans Organic Spa also supports health through nutrition consulting and flotation therapy. They are the only place in central Boston with their private floatation suite, a luxurious room with a shallow pool filled with warm Epsom salt-saturated water. Float and heal into wellness! 

Date: March 8th, 6:30-8:00pm
Location: 216 Newbury St, Boston, MA 02116
RSVP: YES (via http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Scandinavian-Meetup)!
Cost: Free

results.description:
Having collected over 50 Scala Puzzlers so far, we can start to identify certain 'clusters': areas of the language that seem especially prone to puzzling behavior.

In this talk, we'll address the following questions:

1. Which clusters can we identify?
2. Which of these clusters are the result of intrinsic complexity in the language, as opposed to accidental complexity due to implementation?
3. In which cases was the trade-off "worth it:" where does the benefit to Scala developers make up for the additional risk of confusion?

Andrew and Nermin run the scalapuzzlers.com and are authors of the Scala Puzzlers book.
results.how_to_find_us: CarGurus is located directly across from the Lechmere -  Greenline train/bus station and a mile from the Redline at Kendall.  Parking is available at the Galleria Mall.
results.name: Analysing Scala Puzzlers: Essential and Accidental Complexity in Scala

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs
results.name: Climbing at Central Rock (Watertown)

Our lineup of cutting-edge entrepreneurs will dive deep into the challenges and lessons learned of launching a food tech company. We'll be covering early pitfalls of starting a biz, obtaining partners and funding, and reaching buyers and users.

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford Presents EDH Night

results.description:
For March, we will have a talk about communication and collaboration! Designers and developers often have specific goals when creating interactive experiences. Because our creative processes overlap and influence one another, knowing each other’s considerations is key to designing and implementing experiences that are usable and performant. In this presentation, we will see how this balance applies to data visualization. 

A bit about our presenter:


Amanda Cheung (@acacheung) is one of your Meetup organizers and the lead UX developer at DockYard. She is always trying to improve the designer-developer relationship. Passionate about accessibility and CSS architecture, Amanda is also an adjunct professor at MassArt and a teacher for Girl Develop It.

General details:

Doors open at 6:30pm for food and drinks, which will be provided by Vermonster. The talk will start at 7pm. Unfortunately, while Vermonster's old brick building has a lot of charm, it does not have an elevator. We wish that weren't the case.
results.name: Collaborating with Designers

results.description:
RSVP now for Sat, March 5 "First Saturday" (9:45 AM) and/or Wed, Mar 09 (6:45 PM) - Learn valuable do's and don'ts for addressing an audience. Listen to first-time speakers. And discover how to get over that "anxiety hurdle."

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time (and returning) guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Sat, March 5 "First Saturday" (9:45 AM)


Wed, March  23, (6:45 PM)

(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.

results.description:
Urban Dictionary defines chronocentrism as, "the belief that, of all the billions of years of history, the times you live in are the culmination of the workings of the Universe."

In what ways do we see our historical moment as the culmination of the history? In what ways do we feel superior (or inferior) to our ancestors? How does this relate to progress? How does this relate to ancient/older texts and ideas?

results.name: Chronocentrism (aka "chronological snobbery")

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
HARBORLIGHT SHOW CHORUS REHEARSAL

Come sing with our award-winning a cappella/barbershop chorus. Our repertoire includes contemporary pieces from musical hits, jazz standards and classic rock as well as standard barbershop-style arrangements. 

We're a diverse group of women who take our singing seriously and like to have fun too. We're currently auditioning all four voice parts, seeking women of all ages and abilities, with or without a strong musical background. (Sight-reading is helpful but not necessary; sound recordings for individual voice parts are available.) 

Check us out - you'll be glad you did!

results.description:
Meeting the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of every month, this class works from the “Astrology for Yourself” Workbook and it is recommended that you have this available.

This group is for people with advanced beginner or intermediate Astrology knowledge.


This class sets its own agenda dealing with current events, current planetary placement such as lunar cycles or retrograde planets. Discussions are centered on these factors and how they impact us on a more personal level as individuals.

So far this year 2016 we have been focusing mainly on each sign and digging deep into each one by using our own charts and family members charts as examples.


Learning about Astrology but more importantly understanding our own lives creating transformation in our lives because of this deep understanding. 


Come on by and join the fun!

If you need a fresh chart or don't have one and you plan to come please contact me, Dorothy at [masked] with your birth information and I will happily bring one to the meeting.

Dorothy Morgan: Is a Master Astrologer and Personal Consultant with over 27 years’ experience consulting as well as teaching Astrology.
Dorothy has a deep understanding of her own life path and purpose as an Astrologer and she can help you to know what your life path is as well as inspire you to take the steps you need to too follow your own life purpose.


As a teacher Dorothy is practical, logical and we always have a lot of fun in our classes. She uses her sense of humor and Gemini wit to make a complex tool easier to learn.

results.description:
***Change of venue for 3/9 meeting***: As I mentioned in the original meeting notice, we have been looking for a quieter venue for our next Meetup Salon event. I'm pleased to announce that we will be holding it at the home of Danny Hillis and Taylor Milsal in Cambridge. The evening will begin at 7pm <a> </a>with dinner and discussion and then presentation by John Hayes (and two colleagues)


Although Danny will be traveling and unable to join us that evening, Taylor has graciously offered to host us for dinner and discussion. I will post additional details at least a week prior to the Salon.


We have one limitation: we will only have 23 seats for that evening, so sign up quickly. Those who sign up too late will be on a wait list. I will let you know if space opens up.

John Hayes talk:

Descartes Dreamers

Descartes Dreamers was recently started by four grandfathers as a crowd-sourced platform committed to continuing Descartes Dreams and building on the best interpretations of Quantum Physics to improve their lives and the lives of their family, friends, and sentient species everywhere.

The name is inspired by dreams experienced by Rene Descartes <a>on </a><a>November</a><a> 10</a>, 1619 that the mind of man could understand and manage the Universe with mathematics and science. We believe that the work of individuals such as Quantum Physicist David Bohm has greatly enhanced this possibility.

One approach we are exploring is that there is a reality outside of space-time which we are calling “subspace” and which carries a field of intelligence.Perhaps the Universe itself is fully conscious, exhibiting whatBohm calls “Cosmic Intelligence—a collective consciousness that is one and indivisible. If so, is itour responsibility to contribute towards the building of this consciousness of mankind, this “noosphere” that philosopher/paleontologist Pierre Teilhard de Chardin wrote extensively about.

“The universe as we know it is a joint product of the observer and the observed.” 

― Pierre Teilhard de Chardin

Our Facebook page - https://www.facebook.com/descartesdreamers - has been in existence for just over two weeks and has already received over 35,000 Likes from all over the world, especially from India, Pakistan, Brazil, Italy, and Vietnam.

- Adrian Spidle, MIT ‘66

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!

7:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
Our intention in this salon is to build a local community of people interested in personal growth and in sharing that with others. 

This new Heart Beat Salon will meet on the second Wednesday of each month, beginning on March 9, from 7-9 PM. 

The meetings will be facilitated by a different member of the community each month. The first part of each meeting will be a time for people to share the difference personal growth made in their lives over the past month. The experiences shared may be from a new course/offering the person participated in or the result of any growth and development experience they had in the past. They may also share where in their lives  they feel that they need personal growth so that the community, and their participation in the Heart Beat Salon, may support them.

The second part of the evening will be a discussion of a personal growth topic as selected by the facilitator. The facilitator may or may not have in depth knowledge of the topic. Our intention is to hear from a members of the community and to not have this section be led by a professional. 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

begin to establish a new personal growth community.

To Prepare ....

1)  What have been your personal growth experiences?   
2) What area of personal growth are you currently at work on? 
3) Is there personal growth you deem as necessary in your life?

Our Leader This Evening

Nancy and Alan Cantor

Nancy is a PGN organizer and founder of The Dream Factory Community (http://www.dreamfactorycommunity.com/)     and the Entrepreneurs' Connection (http://www.theentrepreneursconnection.com/). 

Alan is a PGN organizer and founder of The Surround and Cantor Coaching (http://www.cantorcoaching.com/).

Links

Most Important:   
  * Other, Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 
  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon?  
  *  Where are Heartbeat Salons  
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Hosts: 
  * How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics to Offer at a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Presenters: 
  * How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Your Suggestions: 
  * Give Us Your Ideas (topics, locations, etc) .
results.name: HBS-Ashland: A Local Personal Growth Community
