results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!

results.description:
*I wasn't going to post this but....for me interesting connections with my favorite composer Ralph Vaughan Williams(RVW). He wanted to study with Elgar but Mrs Elgar said no. RVW and Elgar ended being "friendmies". RVW went on to study with Ravel, for "a little French colour". Ravel said RVW was his only student  "who doesn't write my music".  Some of Ades music seems "RVW like" to me.* 

The usual:

Concert starts at 7:30pm, let's meet at 7:15 *(Please note NEC's change in start time. Most of their concerts now start at 7:30, not 8). 


I will wait just past the "ticket"(no tickets required but they keep track of the # of people entering) area. 

Free and no tickets required.

From Will's description of previous events:

We usually end up sitting in left-middle section of the balcony, since this affords a good view of the entire orchestra, is open to the ceiling, and is easy to describe and find, and it is relatively easy to grab a large block of seats there.

From Kirk: If the balcony is not open(*****It is unlikely that the balcony will be open, based on recent concerts*****), we'll try to sit in the middle section, towards the back. 

Directions to Jordan Hall: 
The hall is located at the corner of Huntington and Gainsborough streets, about a block south of the Symphony T stop on the Green Line. Look for the building with the YMCA sign on top of it--it's near that building. The main entrance is reached from Gainsborough Street.

Price: Free 

Location: NEC's Jordan Hall

Ensemble: NEC Philharmonia

Conductor: Jeffrey Kahane

Artist: Jeffrey Kahane (Piano)

This season, NEC's orchestra programs allow you to discover the music of living composers, alongside familiar masterworks.

BSO audiences will recognize Thomas Adés both as a conductor and a composer. In recent years, Adés has been invited to the BSO as a guest conductor to conduct concerts featuring some of his own music. Others may be familiar with his rather seductive opera "Powder Her Face" (1995), based on the scandalous life of Margaret, Duchess of Argyll. Adés is known for his distinctively creative music, and many consider him to be one of contemporary music’s most gifted composers.

For the Ravel G-Major piano concerto, Jeffrey Kahane will conduct from the keyboard, as in his previous NEC conducting visits.

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.name: Dance Freedom Weekly Dance

results.description:
Limelight Comedy Club is back on Wednesday, March 9 with hilarious headliner Orlando Baxter.

Orlando Baxter exploded onto the Boston comedy scene in 2005, and was quickly established as one of the areas hottest young comics. His fresh perspective and unique relatability soon made this former high school teacher a fan favourite and led to a string of finalist positions in a host of contests and festivals including The New York Comedy Contest, NBC’s ‘Stand Up for Diversity Showcase’ and the Boston Comedy Festival. In 2012 he toured across the U.S. with national headliner Jo Koy, as the opening act in the "Lights Out" tour, before making TV appearances on AXS TV’s ‘Gotham Live’. In 2014, Orlando’s talent took him overseas where he became a finalist at the prestigious Montreux Comedy festival in Switzerland.

Doors open at 7 pm, show at 8pm.

Get Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/limelight-comedy-club-tickets-19117827938

Limelight Comedy Club is Boston's newest stand-up comedy venue, featuring the hottest up and coming comics working today. Located in the heart of Boston's theater district, Limelight Comedy Club is just steps away from the iconic Wilbur Theater, and hosts weekly shows every Wednesday night featuring top talent. $5. 18+.
results.name: Orlando Baxter of Comedy Central and NBC Headlines at Limelight Comedy Club

The Brattle is doing a series of classic film noir, and they're starting off with the classic Laura, directed by Otto Preminger. Seeing this one on the big screen should really highlight the great balck-and-white photography. A film description, from the Brattle's website:

Otto Preminger’s LAURA is a stylish film noir classic centering on a morally bereft group of upper class society types. Title character Laura Hunt (Tierney) has been murdered but retains a prominent part in the picture thanks to a looming portrait. Tough-talking New York detective Mark McPherson (Andrews) investigates the killing and becomes increasingly enamored of the supposedly deceased Laura.


I'll be happy to discuss the film afterwards at Cafe Algiers if folks are interested.

results.description:
This week, we'll be playing Zendo, the beautifully simple game of inductive logic. One player, the master, sets a rule for structures of pieces. For example, they might decide all of the pieces must be different sizes. The other players then have to figure out the rule by building structures and asking if they meet the rule. It's the heart of science captured in a game. You can read more about it here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zendo_(game)

Our schedule is as follows:

• 7:30 Arrival and introductions

• 8pm Game begins

• 11pm End

Attendees are welcome to bring snacks, drinks, or game recommendations.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night: Zendo

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
If you are planning to attend NESEA's BuildingEnergy16 event in Boston (premier regional conference and trade show on green and performance building and renewable energy/energy efficiency) in March, make sure you attend Lisa Fernandes' interactive case study on:

Whole Property Retrofit: Redesigning Suburbia for an Uncertain Energy & Food Future


How do we turn the "problem" of suburbia into an enormous opportunity to create a set of resilient systems that can adapt to a changing world? Learn how a holistic design process and a whole-property retrofit in Maine has created a suburban model of living that requires significantly less time, money and energy to run while simultaneously enhancing the thermal comfort and well-being of the residents. This case study presents a transferable suite of findings on efficiency, renewables, integrated landscape elements, food production, transportation and “incremental deep energy retrofitting” which have weaned this eighty-year-old home completely off of fossil fuels. 


Click here for more info and registration details for BuildingEnergy16

Note that there is an "emerging" professionals discount of 50% off for those who qualify!

Feel free to RSVP here and use the comments area to organize carpools or train/bus group travel.

Here are some sessions from other Mainers schedule for BuildingEnergy16:


On Eggshells: Residential Retrofits in Tricky Situations


Integrated Design for High Performance Buildings

results.description:
The 2016 Henry David Thoreau Prize for Nature Writing.

Chickasaw poet, novelist, essayist, and environmentalist Linda Hogan will receive the 2016 Henry David Thoreau Prize for Nature Writing. Free and open to the public (reservations recommended). More info and reservations HERE.

Thursday, March 10th, 6-7:30pm

MIT Room 2-190, 182 Memorial Drive, Cambridge


“There is a way that nature speaks, that land speaks. Most of the time we are simply not patient enough, quiet enough, to pay attention to the story.” - Linda Hogan


:: :: ::

Linda Hogan is the author of numerous books of poetry, fiction, and nonfiction, most recently Dark / Sweet - New and Selected Poems. 

Intimately connected to her political and spiritual concerns, Hogan’s work deals with issues such as the environment and eco-feminism, the relocation of Native Americans, and historical narratives, including oral histories. Hogan has received grants from the NEA and the Guggenheim Foundation, and her awards include a Lannan Literary Award, an American Book Award, and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Native Writers Circle of the Americas. William Kittredge, in his introduction to Hogan’s Rounding the Human Corners, noted, “poets like Linda, through their language, open for us a doorway into their specific resonating dream of the electric universe.”

Other Linda Hogan poetry collections include: Calling Myself Home (1978); Daughters, I Love You (1981); Eclipse (1983); Seeing Through the Sun (1985), which won the American Book Award from the Before Columbus Foundation; Savings (1988), The Book of Medicines, a National Book Critics Circle Award finalist (1993); and Rounding the Human Corners (2008). 

Hogan’s collections of prose also reflect her interests in the environment and Native American culture. Her publications in prose include: Dwellings: A Spiritual History of the Living World (1995), The Woman Who Watches Over the World: A Native Memoir (2001), and, with Brenda Peterson, Sighting: The Gray Whales’ Mysterious Journey (2002). Her novels include Mean Spirit (1990), Solar Storms(1995), Power (1998), and People of the Whale: A Novel (2008). Together with Brenda Peterson, she also edited the anthology The Sweet Breathing of Plants: Women and the Green World (2001). A recipient of grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation for her fiction, 

Active as an educator and speaker, Hogan taught at the University of Colorado and at the Indigenous Education Institute. She has been a speaker at the United Nations Forum and was a plenary speaker at the Environmental Literature Conference in Turkey in 2009.

Hogan’s awards include a Lannan Literary Award, the Mountains and Plains Booksellers Spirit of the West Literary Achievement Award, and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Native Writers Circle of the Americas.

:: :: ::

The Henry David Thoreau Prize was established in 2010 by writer and naturalist Dale Peterson, and is awarded annually to a writer demonstrating literary excellence in nature writing. Previous winners are Gretel Ehrlich, E. O. Wilson, Gary Snyder, Peter Matthiessen, and T. C. Boyle.
results.name: 2016 Henry David Thoreau Prize for Nature Writing

results.description:
For our March meeting, we're excited to have Max Kuhn back again. He'll be talking about using rule-based models for machine learning. We're also excited to have DataCamp sponsoring the talk and providing us with pizza! Thanks guys!

Max Kuhn is a Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He has been applying models in the pharmaceutical industries for over 15 years. He is a leading R developer and the author of several R packages including the CARET package that provides a simple and consistent interface to over 100 predictive models available in R.


Agenda: 

• 6:00 - 6:30pm - Pizza and networking 

• 6:30 - 7:30pm - Max Kuhn - Rule, Rules, Rules! From Trees to Rules in Machine Learning


Abstract:

Machine learning (aka pattern recognition)(aka predictive modeling) has a long history with tree–based models, such as CART or random forests. However, a parallel set of methodologies have been developed that use rules to create effective predictions (e.g. Quinlan (1992) and Quinlan (1993)). Many of these models are not well known and have not undergone significant peer review but are nonetheless very powerful. Recent developments are bringing a revival of these models. This talk will discuss rule–based models using a port of the Cubist (and C5.0) code to R.
results.name: Rule, Rules, Rules! From Trees to Rules in Machine Learning

results.description:
We gather every month for engaging presentations, lively discussions and craft beer! This group gives security researchers in the Greater Boston community the chance to interact with each other more frequently. Each event features three speakers to talk about something a good hacker finds interesting along with discussions about security processes, techniques and much more!

1. Transportation, Disease, & Consumer Products (6:45-7:10)


By Chris Wysopal | LinkedIn | Wikipedia

The main government approach to cybersecurity has been to think of it through the lens of the military and intelligence community. After all that is where the most expertise lies today. This lens is problematic going forward. We should instead be looking to the way the government thinks of safety: for transportation, disease, consumer products, and the workplace. These are better models for the information security challenge we face. 

About Chris. Chris Wysopal (Weld Pond) is Cofounder and CTO of Veracode, the largest provider of application security as a service. Chris was one of the original security researchers (7th member) in the 90's as a member of the high profile hacker think tank, The L0pht. On May 19, 1998, all seven members of L0pht (Brian Oblivion, Kingpin, Mudge, Space Rogue, Stefan Von Neumann, John Tan, and Weld Pond aka Chris Wyospal) famously testified before the Congress of the United States that they could shut down the entire Internet in 30 minutes. He is a member of the Black Hat Review Board and wrote the book, "The Art of Application Security Testing".

2. Cloud Security & the Full Stack Hack (7:35-8)

By Erik Peterson | LinkedIn

Amazon Web Services (AWS) and other cloud services are billed as an amazingly secure and resilient, but what is the reality? Once you look past that pristine environment and the manicured forests you’ll find a dark jungle. With concrete examples and new techniques this presentation will explore “full stack” vulnerabilities and their effect on security and how they create new pitfalls when migrating to and operating in a Cloud world.

About Erik. Erik Peterson is a member of Veracode’s CTO office where he is the Director of Technology Strategy. His professional experience includes 17 years of security industry experience; consisting of senior and executive leadership roles for Hewlett-Packard, S.P.I. Dynamics, GuardedNet and Sanctum, Inc where he was responsible for technology strategy, research and product management.

Peterson has also held information security positions for Moody’s Investors Service and SunTrust Bank and IT professional roles for the U.S. Embassy in Vienna, Austria and the United Nations International Atomic Energy Agency. He has spoken on the topic of application and cloud security at numerous industry events, including BlackHat EU, Security BSides, OWASP, ISSA, InfraGard and the Cloud Security Alliance.



Schedule


6:00 - 6:30: Craft Beer & Wine

6:30 - 6:35: Cybersecurity Opener by Akshat

6:40 - 6:45: Tool of the month by Will 

6:45 - 7:45:  Chris Wysopal & Erik Peterson

8:00 - 9:00: Network with other security enthusiasts!

Physical Security 

We'd like to make things easy for Security. Everybody should update their meetup profile with their last name and a recent photograph. To do that, click My Profile > View Profile and you'll see the options.

Parking & Public Transportation

Parking is available on premises. Network Drive at Northwest Park offers direct MBTA Bus service to/from the Alewife Red Line T stop in Cambridge and LRTA bus service from Lowell. 

Not receiving emails? 

Some members have said they're not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose Boston Security Meetup under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Why are you charging $1?  

The nominal $1 fee and checkout process serve to verify your attendance and provide a more accurate headcount — and ensure a much better networking experience! Your modest support does enable and encourage us to continue improving these events.

Looking for speakers! 

We're always looking for good speakers and interesting topics for our presentation nights! If you're interested in giving a talk, or have a suggestion for a future event, please contact us. 

Recruiters  

If you would like to attend or mingle with our members in a professional capacity to recruit, please contact us directly about sponsorship opportunities through the Meetup site.
results.name: Transportation, Disease, & Consumer Products

results.description:
March Artist of the Month Opening Reception

Meet the Artist
Dennis Stein
Thursday, March 10th, 6 to 8pm
The Guild’s March Artist of the Month

Dennis will be doing a demo of the Impossible Lab as well.

“In an Instant”
on display will be photos taken using Polaroid, Impossible, and Fuji instant films

Polaroid. What a unique word. What a unique company. At one point in photographic history, it was something one took with a Polaroid camera: a Polaroid photo. From the I-Zone to the SX-70 to 20x24 sheet film, Polaroid was the cool film for creative photographers. It had its quirks, and hence its attraction. It developed differently in cold and hot weather. Surface glitches and color shifts were common with normal and expired film. And you can transfer the image to watercolor paper. So much fun!! In an instant!!
results.name: March Artist of the Month Opening Reception, Meet Dennis Stein

results.description:
LIVE STREAM: http://bit.ly/1pAg8JC

API Crafters!

We'll be focusing on two topics: bending the rules around HTTP verbs and how JSON Schema is far more than just API documentation. We are very fortunate to have two experts presenting, and as always discussion will abound. Food, drink, and A/V will be provided by our sponsor (SmartBear).

Evelyn Liang, Sr. Software Engineer at Nanigans will present


"Verbing Wierds Language"

HTTP verbs are awesome because they provide a common interface for communication. Like all language though, HTTP verbs are often used for things other than their intended purpose. Let's talk about some of these deviations and why bending the rules is okay sometimes.


Pete Gamache, Head of Engineering at Appcues will also present

JSON Schema: Your API's Secret Weapon

JSON Schema is a language for defining the shape of JSON structures using JSON itself.  We'll explore how, in addition to being a useful piece of API documentation, JSON Schema is a valuable tool for validating and enforcing the format of an API's input and output.

Hope to see you all there!

results.name: HTTP Verbs and JSON Schema

What is Inner Engineering?

Inner Engineering is a method, a tool to engineer a deep and lasting personal transformation. 
It is a combination of methods and technologies derived from the ancient science of yoga. 
It is a comprehensive system addressing every aspect of human wellbeing – from body, mind and emotion to the fundamental life energy within us.

Over two million people have completed the “Inner Engineering” program worldwide and have reported remarkable results. The program includes engaging discourses exploring the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life situations, along with guided meditations, group discussions, simple yoga postures, and a powerful and purifying energy technique designed to bring one’s entire system into alignment and harmony.

What does the program offer?

- Enlightening interactive sessions,

- Guided MeditationsAsanas, simple yoga postures,

- Shambhavi Mahamudra, a powerful , 21-minute energy technique that brings your entire system into alignment so that your body, mind, emotions and energies function in harmony.

Benefits

- Improved mental clarity,sleep quality, and increased energy levelsAbility to handle stressful situations effortlessly. 

- Deepening of interpersonal relationships, thus cultivating a greater sense of connectivity at home, work and in the community

- Helps to purify the five elements (earth, water, fire, air, space) in the body leading to pleasantness in the body, mind and emotionRelief from chronic ailments.

- Access to the intelligence and competence within, which is the very source of creationGreater peace and joy in everyday life 

Who Should Attend?

- The program is for anyone age 14+, with no requirements of previous experience or physical agility. This is not about becoming strong or learning to stand on your head, but it is a technology for looking at the fundamentals of your life and nurturing your complete wellbeing. The technology of Inner Engineering is like driving a car – no matter what your background, beliefs, religion, or culture, if you learn to drive the car properly, it will take you places!

results.description:
I'll be showing how the Xilinx ISE 14.7 WebPack toolchain works to program a Nexys 2 Spartan-3E FPGA trainer board. This is to help everyone, especially those without FPGA experience, see how easy it is to actually test a design in an FPGA. The demo will be done using my Surface Pro 3 w/ Win10 tablet and a couple of simple design circuits, nothing fancy. I just want to show how simple it is.


Here's an example implementation of a simple 4 bit sign-magnitude adder circuit using the 8 switches and 2 buttons [btn 0, btn1] as inputs and the seven segment display for output.

In the images below a + b =c or -6 + 3 = -3

a: lower 4 switches = -6


b: upper 4 switches = 3, display appears when btn 0 pressed


c: sum of a + b appears when btn 1 is pressed
results.name: Demo of Xilinx ISE FPGA Toolchain

Mainstream Meditation, Level 1
Everyday mindfulness for everyone

Presented by Elizabeth Phillips, a Master Level Reiki practitioner, Level 1 Crystal Healer and a Certified Meditation Teacher; certified through Andy Kelley "The Boston Buddha" and Meditation For Everyone (MFE).

Mainstream Meditation is a four week workshop focusing on introducing a meditation and mindfulness practice into your every day life.  The goal of this workshop is to teach participants to be able to slow down and recharge through meditation.

This basic meditation workshop is for beginners as well as anyone who would like to refresh their understanding of meditation and mindfulness techniques.

Week 1: What is meditation and why are we here? / Focus Meditation Week 2: Roadblocks and expectations / Mantra Meditation

Week 3: Creating a space between stimulus and response /Mindfulness based meditation

We will be working on the floor so be sure to wear comfortable clothing, and bring a pillow to sit on (the studio has some bolsters as well).

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.

We gather to meditate, share our stories, and engage in practices that expand our moral imagination, get real about the social and ecological crisis our world is in, and renew our sense of hope and purpose in regards to the Great Turning towards a life-sustaining society.

The people in our group share a common journey of waking up to our interconnection with life around us. We are discovering what it means to be a part of Earth and to choose to be part of the process of Earth's self-healing.  In our meetings we engage in processes and practices from the Work That Reconnects, a type of group work or spiritual practice for activists who are seeking Earth's healing and justice for Earth's peoples. 

Please join us.  No prior experience with the Work That Reconnects is required, though if you do have experience that is great.  Periodically there are 1-day experiential trainings in the Boston area we can connect you with.

Our Work That Reconnects Praxis Group meets once a month on a weekday evening from 7-9pm.  Newcomers are always welcome.

results.description:
Come see how the Yieldbot core infrastructure team is using golang to enhance and extend it's current monitoring capabilities across both virtual and container environments.

Yieldbot is writing both effective monitors and notification channels in golang that utilize Sensu as a monitoring router but also conform to the 12 Factor App theory to maximize portability across multiple Linux distributions.

Matt Jones will share some of the design patterns and issues that needed to be solved in order to build consistent binaries and libraries that could be used not only at Yieldbot but at other companies. All code, slides, and docs shared will be made available via Github under an MIT license.
results.name: How Yieldbot Uses Golang For Monitoring

results.description:
Crossroads Irish Pub (Boston,  Beacon St and Mass Ave intersection) 7 pm to 10 pm

Due to requests and great turnout, Japanese Evening Table is going back to Crossroads! Grab a few drinks and some delicious cheap bar food. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking in the area is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. Also, watch out for those hidden street cleaning signs! If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway to Hynes or bus #1 to stop between Beacon and Marlborough.

Ordering at Crossroads: 

1) Order all your drinks and food at the bar. 

2) Start a tab (付け) or pay as you go. Don't forget to tip. 

See you there!
~Lindsay

results.description: Come check out dragon boating with Living Root! We're a co-ed dragon boat team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. Walk through the outdoor basketball courts to the rear of the building to find the pool entrance. Take the stairs down to the ground floor and head through the locker rooms to get to the pool. Practice will begin poolside at 7 pm. Wear athletic clothing. Although we won't do any swimming, you will get somewhat wet. Parking is free in the school parking lot. The T station at Porter Square is a 5 minute walk away. Practice will last an hour and 45 minutes. We provide paddles and all the necessary equipment--just bring yourself! results.description:
This is a 4 week course. If you RSVP for this date you are RSVPing for the complete 4 week course. Please only RSVP if you are committed to attending to the whole series.


This course introduces students to the basic principles of 3D modeling, such as how to navigate in 3D space, what 3D models are made out of, and how to create simple forms and objects. The software used will be Sketchup, a free program that is excellent for beginners and professionals alike. Students will learn the ins and outs of the program, from basic techniques to advanced modeling concepts. This series is for people who have not already taken a 3D modeling class at HATCH.


Requirements:


• A free copy of Sketchup. 

• A CAD-capable laptop or desktop. The computer must have a discrete graphics chip or a very new (last three years) onboard graphics chip.


• A three button (minimum) mouse.


• You must be an experienced Windows or Mac user.


• You should be able to utilize keyboard shortcuts and understand how to use computer file systems.


*If you need a laptop please contact the organizer, we have six laptops available for use. We prefer that you use your own for this class.*

If you are bringing your own computer, please pre-load Sketchup Make. You can download it from www.sketchup.com.
results.how_to_find_us: We're located in the Arsenal Project (formerly Arsenal Mall). Park in the lot near Old Navy entrance, you'll see a big yellow-green sign over the doors. HATCH is between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Modeling (4 week class)

We all dream of sending our children off to college but with the national average cost of attending a four-year public college is over $28,000 per year and the average cost of attending a four-year private college is over $59,000, that dream may seem hard to reach. College is a big investment but there are strategies to help make this important goal much more affordable.

In this workshop, run by SFP Wealth, we will discuss:

• How are you going to pay for college.

results.description:
MOSES GREELEY PARKER LECTURES PRESENTS:
AN EVENING WITH TY BURR: THE 50 MOVIE STARTER KIT

Boston Globe movie critic, Ty Burr, tells you what you need to know if you want to know what you’re talking about when it comes to movies! Join Ty as he covers over a century of filmmaking and introduces us to the 50 films every movie lover should know, from American favorites to international classics. This cinematic journey is perfect for beginning film lovers as well as those who want to ramp up their passion for the art form.

ABOUT TY: Ty Burr has been a film critic for the Boston Globe since July 2002. Prior to that, he worked for Entertainment Weekly as the magazine’s chief video critic, and also covered film, music, theater, books, and the internet. In addition to three books, Ty has written articles on film and other subjects for the New York Times, Spin, the Boston Phoenix, and other publications, and he regularly appears on WBUR’s “Here and Now,” WGBH’s “Greater Boston,” MSNBC News, and NPR’s “All Things Considered.” A member of the National Society of Film Critics and the Boston Society of Film Critics, Ty studied film at Dartmouth College and New York University and is currently an adjunct professor in the Film & TV department of Boston University. Learn more about Ty at TyBurr.com.

This event is FREE and is FIRST COME, FIRST SEATED.
results.name: An evening with Ty Burr: Boston Globe Movie Critic: 100+ years of moviemaking

It's hard with the mixed and evolving messages to do it all and be healthy. We'd all be healthy and fit if that's all we had to do in a day, but with jobs, commitments, family, and getting enough sleep, it's tricky. Learn effective and efficient concepts to use right away for Whole Health Life. You can succeed and have more time for other things.

Seating is limited so please register here; https://welleffect.com/events/

results.description:
Well that got your attention!

Have you ever wondered if there was more available in sex and connection? Maybe you’ve had glimpses of something, but can’t figure out how to revisit that place?

Learn a new definition of orgasm, and a new perspective on how it can fuel your life. Orgasm is so much more complex than sex - let’s talk about the full spectrum on Thursday night! 

We will also answer your questions about the practice called Orgasmic Meditation (OM), which can give you access to energy, vitality, and your own orgasm in a way you never expected. 

Maybe you’re curious: Could this practice help you feel more connected to the people you care about? More connected with yourself? More aware of and attentive to your own desire (of all categories, not just about sex)? And who are these people who OM?

Get your questions answered, hear details about the practice, and why thousands around the globe consider it to be one of the most transformational practices they have. And, decide whether you’re ready to have this powerful, nourishing practice in your life! We have a class where you can learn all about it coming right up—on Saturday. (plus there’s a special discount for registering at this event!)

$10, payable at the door. Please allow plenty of time to park/walk and arrive by 7:30 - we will start promptly.

If you are ready to dive right into taking the class, click here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-intro-to-om-orgasmic-meditation-march-2016-tickets-21071725097

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. Here’s a TED talk by the founder of OM, Nicole Daedone: http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm-Th
results.name: The Truth About Orgasm, & Saturday’s Class

results.description:
NOTE: This *was* labeled "a little tentative," but no longer - this is a definite go. :)

Join fellow LGBT folks for some informal bowling! The score isn't important - having fun and enjoying the company is! We usually have a wide range of abilities attend.

We're trying out a new home for this one - Metro Bowl near Peabody Square in Peabody. Metro Bowl has Candlepin lanes (narrower pins and smaller balls then Ten-Pin bowling).

RSVP:

By 5:30, day of event. If you forget to RSVP, you can still come (and should!) - I can *almost* guarantee you'll get to bowl.


MEETING PLACE:

By 7:30 - Inside Metro Bowl, by the front desk.


COSTS:

To be split among the group: Metro Bowl charges $4.50 per string and $3.00 for shoe rental (it will likely come to around $12 each).

I am not currently asking for an event fee to cover Meetup's charges, but donations are welcome (go to "Support Your Group" on the home page).


DIRECTIONS:

Metro Bowl is located at 63 Foster Street, a couple blocks from Peabody Square.

From Route 128, take exit 26 "Lowell St" and turn towards Peabody Square.

When you reach Peabody Sqaure (after about 3/4 to 1 mile), turn right onto Foster Street.

The second right is Franklin Street. Metro Bowl is right there. 


YOUR HOST...

Will be Chris - the six foot tall guy with the goatee. If you're running late or are lost, you can call or text me at  [masked] (Note this new cell number - and that every now and then it doesn't get coverage at my home.)

results.description:
After talking with a few of you at the reception we came up with, "Sharing Our Bliss” for the 2016 May-July Exhibit. Our goal has always been to hang quality photos that provide a happy distraction to those passing through the oncology wing. What better way than to share what brings peace and happiness to our own souls.

Guidelines as I’ve made them up so far are:
Everyone will be added as going on Mar 14th, however those who RSVP "Yes" prior to the meet up date will have access to downloading images starting on Mar 11th. March 11th Submission Entry Begins
1. Max number of submissions: 3 images
2. Include “The Image Title” by clicking on the “Add caption” field under uploaded images
3. Images can be vertical, horizontal, square, and panoramic, but max horizontal width is 24” including a frame.
4. File size for the MeetUp site must be under 10MB*
* PLEASE make sure your File Size is Large Enough to Enlarge Well without deterioration of the image quality.

March 27th 10AM Entry Cut Off
March 27th 5PM Voting Starts
Voting Guidelines
1. Choose your favorite 19 images Submitted By OTHER Photographers by adding a "VOTE" comment**
2. If we have over 20 people submitting images than only 1 image per person will be chosen so we can include as many people as the walls allow
3. ANYONE in the group can vote and we encourage EVERYONE that entered an image to do so
**Vote like you were the person choosing the images to be in the show

April 6th Voting Ends
April 8th Chosen Photos Announced


April 15th Print Info & Wall Card Info Due
Email [masked] with the following information:
1. Your Name as you want to see it in the exhibit
2. Image Title
3. If you are providing a Matted Print (16”x20”) or a Canvas, Metal, or Wired Hang Ready Framed Print (max horizontal width including frame 24”)
4. Dimensions if smaller than 16” x 20”
5. Price if you are offering your image for sale
6. Email Address
7. Phone Number (contact info to be included in the pricing sheet)
8. City of Residence
9. A 1 or 2-paragraph story about the image and/or you the photographer (people appreciate the story behind the image and photographer)

April 22nd Final Day for Image Drop Off
Drop off at Ginny’s house
28 River St, Erving, MA 01344
Or contact Ginny by email, text, or phone to make arrangements (Mobile:[masked]) April 22nd 6:30PM Framing & Hanging Gathering
Anyone interested in helping with the framing and hanging will be welcome to come. The last 2 shows took us about an hour to frame, an hour to socialize, half an hour to transport, and an hour to hang.

Remember we have plenty of 16’ x 20’ frames generously donated by Beth available for this use if you prefer to provide a matting print.

We continue receive fantastic feedback from oncology visitors and the hospital staff over our current show. People have really been enjoying the images and the wall cards too. Looking forward to seeing your images for this next show!
results.name: Call for Photos - Baystate Franklin Oncology Wing - “Sharing Our Bliss"”

SUBJECTS 11-13

11 Landscape: Reflection - Find a way to show your landscape/natural beauty in reflection.


12 Artistic: Transportation - Our world is one defined by how we get around. Literal or interpretative, find inspiration in transportation.


13 Portrait: High Key- Expose to the right and create a light, airy high key portrait.


*** Upload 1 or 2 images per subject max.
*** Please try to Caption your work.
*** Please make constructive, appreciative comments on a minimum of 2 other images for every image you post.
*** 1 image from your library can be shared per subject, but the object is to take new images.
*** Images should be uploaded between Mar 11th and Apr 10th

If anyone has suggestions or an on-line source that would be helpful to a specific subject, please share in the comments for the challenge.

What can you do with an effective social media program?

• Raise awareness about your products and services

• Engage with customers to keep them coming back for more

• Reach prospects

But too often, business owners aren’t taking advantage of these resources because they don’t know where to begin. Or, they get started full of enthusiasm only to get discouraged when it doesn’t seem to work. They need a strategy and a plan to get the program going and keep it on track.

Learn how to make social media work for your business.


At this hands-on seminar, you will: 

• Discover how to use the popular social media channels to promote your business

• Develop a plan to launch a sustainable social media program

• Network with other business owners

March 11, 9 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. at the Beacon Business Club, 185 Winthrop Street, Winthrop, MA 02152

$50 includes two-and-a-half hour interactive workshop and 30-minute follow-up phone consultation.

results.description:
Are you a mom who yearns to fulfill your passions through the freedom and flexibility of entrepreneurship, but you're not willing to sacrifice your family priorities? This course is created to build your confidence to build a business around your family.

Motherhood and entrepreneurship do not have to be mutually exclusive. Whether you're a full time working mom hoping to leave the rat race, or a stay at home mom hoping to reactiviate your career with something flexible, this course will show you the best ways to ramp up a side business safely, rapidly and more profitably, all while putting your family, heart and soul at the center.

Attend this workshop to:

- Establish your lifestyle plan before diving into your business plan

- Build a business strategy that works around your personal and family priorities

- Walk away feeling confident in a lifestyle plan that works for your family, a business plan that leverages your passions and is poised to bring in income, and critical time management strategies that enable you to maintain inner and outer peace as your business grows at a pace that works for you and your family.

This workshop has a $20 fee, but partial scholarships may be available to those who qualify. You can register directly online here: http://www.cweonline.org/NewsEvents/ViewArticle/tabid/164/ArticleId/1277/Mompreneurs-Kickstarting-a-Business-Plan-that-works-for-your-Family-CWE-Eastern-MA-February-12.aspx

For scholarship info and all other questions, please contact Madeleine Lutts at [masked] or[masked]

Note:  Pose will be the same as the Saturday 3-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Four hours each Friday morning, 10:00- 2:00pm. You can come individual days by paying $20 (members) or $30 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
All Are Invited: Lunchtime Meet Up at Rebecca's Café!
 SPC members have long expressed an interest in an additional channel for unstructured networking and just plain schmoozing about their business triumphs and trials.
Here's how it works: You just show up! No need to pay a fee.
Rick Pollack of Presentation Medic, a member of the SPC Board, has volunteered to anchor this gathering. This meeting is a bring your own agenda, or just enjoy lunch with other consultants.
Find yourself something appealing to nosh on, settle at the cash register, and join the group. We've picked 1 p.m. on a Friday as our start time to avoid the crush and let people take as much time as they feel they can afford...and maybe start a new conversation they can pick up later!
Mark your calendar now ... you don't even have to sign up on our website!

results.description:
2nd part of a three part gaming series.

What role does race play in gaming? Does it? At the first session in this series (on November 30th) we explored gaming as a strategy towards liberation and community building. This session we will explore gaming as a tool to deconstruct whiteness. Is it at all possible? When we think about the gaming community, both tabletop gaming and video gaming, the demographics look pretty homogenous (predominantly white males), can we adopt and adapt gaming as a tool to deconstruct racism? In what ways does gaming perpetuate structural racism?

Participants from the March 5th playtest and other previous game-related meetups are welcome to attend and share their experiences, but prior attendance at one of those meetups is NOT required.
results.name: Gaming and Race

results.description:
Let's play party group games!

Mexican Train Game
Heads Up
Michigan Rummy (for nickels)
Kitty Whist (card game)

All of these games are easy to play - no experience necessary! We are a friendly bunch who teach new players how to play. We are NOT competitive nor intimidating!!!! In fact, sometimes we are learning some new games and need to read the directions and figure it out together!

Mexican Train Game is a domino matching game (anyone can learn)
Heads Up is like 20 questions
Michigan Rummy is a simple card game, easy and fun! We each start with $4 in nickels...yes, we ante up each hand, but the stakes aren't high and most people break even...! It's as easy as 1-2-3.
Kitty Whist is a trump-taking card game played with partners. We rotate people in if there's an odd number...no worries!
We meet outside of Fuddrucker's. No time scheduled for eating - eat dinner, or not, as you please. There's also Richardson's Ice Cream and Beantown Jelly Beans. It's a fun venue and who knows, Elliot might even join us for a picture or two!

If you can't make it right at 6, that's fine. It's a come and go type of event, but please rsvp so we have an idea of how many are coming. Friends are welcome too. This will be cross-posted with NSWG and Salem Social Cards.
results.name: Games and cards:  Jordan's Friday 3/11

*This is not a Cannabis Society event.*  Cannabis Society members get discounted $25 tickets through this Eventbrite URL:  www.tinyurl.com/sweet-infusions

Cannabis Society does not know the location of the event. The location of event is apparently revealed after purchasing the ticket through eventbrite.

Cannabis Society members have been invited to the second installment of Activate Gourmet Events hosted by Ardent Cannabis. This time it's all about the sweets! Chocolates, gummies, and baked goods are a delicious way to administer herbal therapy, but there's more to proper consumption than meets the eye. 

How is it possible to accurately dose with edibles? 

What are the best methods for creating the most effective treats? 

Join Ardent and Northern Herb for a night of education, collaboration, and hands on demonstrations and discussions with the experts. 

The night will begin with networking and refreshments, followed by rotating hands-on demonstrations and discussions, including Cannabis 101: Strains, Dosing, and Administration for the Modern User, Cannabis as a Wellness Tool, and Sweet Infusion Techniques (featuring Ardent's new Instant Truffles!). 

Laugh, learn, and get your hands deliciously dirty as we share and explore the new frontier of herbal healing. *We are excited to have professional coordination of the event to ensure a smooth and organized experience that allows everyone the chance to participate in the demo and ed sessions. 

Positive ID required. Every attendee must be ticketed for this event. Registered Medical Patients BYOC.

Event is located in Milton MA, exact address provided upon ticket purchase.

Check out Ardent's last event www.tinyurl.com/activate-album

Buy Tickets:  www.tinyurl.com/sweet-infusions

Legal Disclaimer 

Views or opinions expressed by speakers or sponsors at cross-posted Cannabis Society events do not express the opinion or views of the Cannabis Society organization and we do not take responsibility for the views expressed or the actions of speakers or sponsors at these cross-posted events. The Cannabis Society does not distribute cannabis in anyway shape or form.

The Cannabis Society is Growing  

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.
results.name: Activate II: Sweet Infusions & Canna Basics

results.description:
National Parks Adventure playing at the Museum of Science

MacGillivray Freeman's National Parks Adventure takes you on the ultimate IMAX® off-trail adventure into the nation's awe-inspiring great outdoors and untamed wilderness. Spectacularly wild and beautiful places like Yosemite, Yellowstone, the Everglades, the Redwoods, Arches, and Canyonlands are illuminated as never before with immersive giant-screen cinematography, revealing a tapestry of natural wonders that will inspire the adventurer in us all.


National Parks Adventure follows in the tradition of MacGillivray Freeman's award-winning Great Adventure Films—including Everest, Dolphins, Journey Into Amazing Caves, and Grand Canyon Adventure — that are set in some of the most extraordinary locations on the planet.

The show starts at 7 PM and you can buy your tickets in advance. We'll meet at 6:30 pm which gives us time to peruse the museum store, grab a snack at the cafe if desired, and get seated.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the red wing atrium. To the left of entrance, past the cafe and store.
results.name: IMAX Film: National Park Adventure at MOS

results.description:
Ok, let's tweak our program a little in order to encourage those of you who might still be intimidated by the night sky just a little. The idea of a love for the night sky brings to mind a poem by Sarah Williams: "Though my soul may set in darkness, it will rise in perfect light; I have loved the stars too fondly to be fearful of the night". Please attend this "Introduction To The Night Sky" event bringing only a curiosity to know more about what you're seeing when you look up on a clear night in your back yard. If you have binoculars or even a telescope, you'll be able to see many many more interesting treasures of the night sky, so please bring them. This month we're going to have a "Deep Sky Treasure Hunt" The idea is to go out into the night looking for the following "Treasures"
A "First Magnitude" star
An "Open Star Cluster"
A "Globular Star Cluster"
A "Double Cluster" of Stars
A "Galaxy"
Your favorite winter "Constellation"
A "King Constellation"
A "Queen Constellation"
A "Heroic Constellation"
A "Dragon Constellation"
A "Daughter of The King & Queen Constellation"
A "Bear Constellation"
The "Seven Sisters" Constellation
A "Swan Constellation"
A "Double Star"
A "Blue Colored Star"
A "Red Colored Star"
An "Orange Colored Star"
A "White Colored Star"
A "Pinkish Colored Star"
A "Yellowish Colored Star"
A "Greenish Colored Star"
A "Stellar Nursery" (Where stars are in the process of being born)
An "Emission Nebula"
Please know that you are welcome as long as you plan to participate in these discoveries as a group. I will have binoculars and a large telescope for all to see through to aid in our observations. I'll bring some wine and some cheese to refresh us while we observe. Please dress warmly in layers as it can get chilly very quickly once the sun goes down.
results.name: Wine & Cheese & A Beginner's Introduction to The Night Sky

results.description:
As usual, we've got a great line up of comedians at The Gas this week, including special guest Jono Zalay!

Several years ago Jono Zalay moved from San Diego to Boston to pursue standup. He quickly became a staple in the New England comedy scene, while simultaneously earning his Doctorate in Neuroscience (he gave cocaine to rats). Since dropping his science hobby to pursue stand-up full time, Jono has been invited to perform in the Bridgetown, Limestone and New York Comedy Festivals. Jono now lives in New York City where he has been featured in Time Out New York and the Final Four of Caroline’s March Comedy Madness. His background in science brings a unique perspective to his stand up and provides the insight for his popular comedy-science podcast Universe City.

18+ hosted by Rob Crean $5

FB: https://www.facebook.com/events/1556579351327789/
results.name: The Gas! with special guest Jono Zalay!

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a free seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, will even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Ever wondered how to make all those cool noises with a turntable and mixer? Felt that burning desire to scratch up your parents record collection as a child? Or questioned how a turntable could be used as an instrument? Mmmmaven's introduction workshop will provide you with the basics to scratching and beat juggling, whether you're looking to become a turntables or just add some flare to your DJ sets. No experience required and all skill levels are welcome. Come prepared to get busy!

DJ Rugged One has been in the game for many years and has firmly established a name for himself in the industry as a professional deejay and producer. Spinning at numerous bars, lounges & clubs, he effortlessly creates a vibe that keeps the dance floor packed. His passion for music naturally led him into the realm of music production, where he actively takes on remix projects and creates brand new material with a plethora of skilled artists. Rugged One earned his stripes during his years as a competitive DJ, placing as a finalist in many battles, never failing to intimidate and turn heads! He continues to be sought after and commissioned to create mix CDs for respected organizations in the hip hop realm, including Undergroundhiphop.com, Brick Records and others, all while juggling his own independent releases. Receiving notable praise in a vast array of publications & websites, Rugged has evolved over the years to become the "total package," a DJ who can satisfy the purest of hip hop heads, the wildest of college club-goers and everything in between, taking you on a musical trip in the process. He enjoys what he does and is a true entertainer. DJ Rugged One…the man, the myth, the DJ... go on, go on and GET DOWN!

DJ Competitions:
2008-DMC New Orleans Regional Finalist-3rd Place2007-DMC USA Finalist2006-DMC Boston, MA Regional Finalist -2nd place.DMC Washington, DC Regional Finalist-3rd place2005-DMC New York City Regional Finalist Competed in other battle organizations such as I.T.F., Kool Mixx ,Guitar Center & local competitions.
results.name: Scratching Workshop w/ DJ Rugged One [3/11] #FREE

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

James Montgomery Band:When blues legend James Montgomery plays the harmonica, he "brings it on home". Whether it's recording with Kid Rock, sitting in with Gregg Allman, or fronting his hot band of thirty years, Montgomery plays with authority. While growing up in Detroit he learned first-hand from the masters - James Cotton, John Lee Hooker, and Jr. Wells - at the legendary "Chessmate." Over the years, he's carried on in the tradition and continues to be a vital presence in Blues as one of the most dynamic performers on the scene.

results.description:
Dance with us from 8:00 pm - midnight at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

The night will start with a class from 8:00 to 9:00, open to all ages and experience levels. We will warm up with basic stretching and get into groups of two for some partner stretching (no partner needed, we will pair up during class). Here we will learn how to use one another's support to deepen the practice of stretching. We will progress to groups of three for an introduction to acro-yoga beginning with L-Base moves. We will learn how to be birds, folded leaves, and even how to sit on a throne through our exploration of acro-yoga. 

Music provided by 

DJ Gluten Free Girlfriend (https://soundcloud.com/glutenfreepineapple)

Dan Paikowsky

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome. We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can move in.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.

Please do not let the cost be the reason you do not attend. If you truly cannot afford the donation speak with one of the organizers and something will be worked out.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours

results.name: Astronomy After Hours - Museum of Science

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join us for a night of west coast swing. We offer a beginner ("Level 1", meant for those with little/no experience), intermediate ("Level 2", meant for those who have mastered the Left Side Pass, Right Side Pass, and Sugar Push), and advanced ("Level 3", meant for those who have mastered whips, tucks, and fundamental techniques) classs from 8:30-9:30pm. If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-12pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, country and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Second-Friday-of-the-Month West Coast Swing Classes & Social Dance!

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike three of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Bond, Bondcliff, and West Bond. I am planning trips in February, March (will also include Zealand), and April (will also include Hale and Zealand) so I'm going to do each hike using a different route. Here are the details for each of the three events:

• February - Bondcliff, Bond, and West Bond as an out and back from Lincoln Woods. This one will get you three 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 4,200 feet of climbing. It will take about 12 hours 30 minutes to complete. (this will be a "winter" hike)


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265


• March - Zealand, West Bond, Bond, and Bondcliff traverse from Zealand Road to Lincoln Woods. This one will get you four 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 4,000 feet of climbing. It will take about 12 hours 30 minutes to complete. (this will be a "winter" hike)


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/31-Mt-Zealand-4260

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265

• April - Hale, Zealand, West Bond, Bond, and Bondcliff traverse from Fire Warden Trail up Hale to Lincoln Woods. This one will get you five 4Ks and is about 21 miles with about 5,300 feet of climbing. It will take about 13 hours 15 minutes to complete. (this will be a "spring" hike)

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/37-Mt-Hale-4054


• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/31-Mt-Zealand-4260

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/14-Mt-Bond-4698--16-West-Bond-4540--30-Bondcliff-4265

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.16811703400049&lon=-71.53396885799964&site=all&smap=1#.VpccTjblweJ


=== What to Bring ===


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Lincoln Woods Visitors Center which is located on the north side of Route 112 east of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 135 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 10 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will end the day we will leave a few cars there and drive to the starting spot.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• </a>https://goo.gl/maps/fnmNxuEiKxm

<a href="https://goo.gl/maps/NhpBuQBan5R2">

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
