results.description:
Sunday, March 13
Revere and Winthrop Seabirds
We will be targeting sea birds that we typically do not get inland around Arlington: loons, grebes (especially red-necked), great cormorant, goldeneye, perhaps three species of scoter, long-tailed duck, gulls, and possibly more pelagic species if winds are off the water. We will car pool from the meeting place to various sites. Please contact leader by e-mail if you are coming, being sure to note if you need a ride. Meet at the traffic circle parking at the south end of Revere Beach Boulevard. 9:00 AM (don’t forget this is the first day of daylight savings time) Karsten Hartel

results.description: The course is listed on Mapmyrun.com  under Waltham Bandit Half.   An unofficial time keeper http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/339251611 will start a watch for the run and if you want to wear an old number feel free.  Just like any other training run roads are open and caution must be used.  This is self sustaining run with gas stations/store located at mile 7 and again at 11 if you need to use restrooms, food or water.   No registration, no water stops, food, road markings or any other formalities are offered just the chance to push your training limits with a great group.

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The time has changed and sneakers are not recommended. Parking will be at my house the request to use the parking lot has been denied. 


Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

results.description:
Let's have a healthy start to the new year - come run a 5K with us!  

Need to train? Here's a link to various training programs, depending on your current fitness level:  http://www.halhigdon.com/training/50932/5K-Training-The-Most-Popular-Racing-Distance 

Race details (includes a link to registration): http://www.cambridge5k.com/craicfest/ 

Post party: Last year, it was in the garage of the mall (so it will be warm enough). There are awards for best times, fastest teams, and best costumes.  Maybe someone can dress up like a pot of gold? The rest of us can dress up as leprechauns and chase them?   The music at the after party is usually awesome.  


Full disclosure: I'm part of a team.  The folks on my team are a very diverse group and have a lot of spirit. Our times vary from under 25 minutes to 60+ minutes.  For us, it's just about getting out there and doing it (walk or run).  Currently, we have enough people to secure a post-race table in the VIP section, complete with beverages.  (WOO HOO!  Instant VIP for you!)  If we get enough people, we can have our table catered as well - no more long lines for pretzels and pizza.  Team name to use when registering: Finishers Fit Club

This should be fun!!
results.how_to_find_us: The food court.  We can arrange a carpool from Arlington as well.
results.name: Craicfest - Cambridge 5K

results.description:
We'll check out Doane's Falls then head out on the Tully Trail to Spirit Falls and the Ledges and return. Total approx 5 mi.

Consider this to be a Easy/Moderate hike with a few ascents that may be difficult!

Possible after hike stop at The Old Mill. 


http://www.1761oldmill.com/


<a></a>

The Fine Print:

Duration: Approximately 3-4 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted.

If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated easy/moderate.  You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace of 2+ mph. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the leader, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

NO DOGS and NO GUESTS are allowed on this hike. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. (woof!) If you need everything to run perfectly this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.c... the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.
results.name: Tully Trail to Spirit Falls and the Ledges

results.description:
Sponsored by Boston Nature Center and Boston Area Beekeepers Association

Instructor: Bill Perkins - Boston Area Beekeepers Association

Mass Audubon Members: $25.00

Mass Audubon Nonmembers: $30.00

Nonmembers can join today during checkout and take immediate advantage of member prices.

Did you know that you can enjoy bees and bee products right in your backyard? Urban yards (and even rooftops) are often excellent locations for beehives. In this introductory workshop, you will learn about the fascinating world of the honeybee. We will talk about what it takes to keep a busy, productive hive of bees happy; how to set up and maintain a hive; and what kind of time commitment is required. This is a beginner’s workshop, so no previous knowledge is necessary. We will end with some local honey tasting. Fee: $25 members / $30 nonmembers. Registration is not required, but recommended. Walk-ins are welcome.

Registration is required. 

Register online or call[masked] to register by phone.

Register by mail: program registration form (PDF 66K)

For more information, contact: Boston Nature Center, Mattapan, MA 02126, [masked]
results.name: Beekeeping 101 : An Introduction to Honey Bees as a Hobby

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $75 or $90 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
Hi introverts,

What better way to take advantage of the coming warm weather while getting into the spring/Easter spirit than wandering around a lovely and very kid-friendly farm.  If you are new to Drumlin Farm, it is run by the Mass Audubon society and is a working farm with some extra attractions of interest to kids.  The current forecast for March 13th is a low of 40 and high of 55 for the day - a good enough day to get outside.  Hiking boots are recommended for the dirt paths, but they are well maintained and most are easy for little feet.


For those that aren't Mass Audubon members, most libraries offer discount tickets if you reserve them in advance.
results.name: Let's visit Drumlin Farm in Lincoln, MA on Sunday, March 13 at 9:30 am

results.description: Hello Bonefish lovers! (of which I am one.) We are having brunch at 10AM on Sunday March 13th at the Bonefish Grill. I love the California Omelet and have a craving for it. (Correct me if I am wrong, but daylight savings time starts that night and not the day of the 13th.) Vaughn OK'd us for twelve diners and individual checks. Do bring cash if at all possible for ease of payment and do tip bet. 18-20% since a large group taxes the staff. I have always enjoyed our brunches at Bonefish. If you are new to the location know that there is a lovely mall directly across for a little shopping afterwards. If you wish to bring a friend add a plus one when you say "yes" to attending. Should you change your mind about attending, go back to where you said yes and make that a no. Those on the waitlist will automatically move up to  attending. You have until 9 PM the night prior to decide to attend. Thanks all.

results.description:
Let's kick-off our DST Spring Forward Sunday Morning w/ a Walk @ Pond Meadow Park (PMP) in Braintree!  Our clocks spring forward 1 hour today so 10am will feel like 9am!!  A walk will help us all!  This is one of our favorite walking locations. on the South Shore.  We will be meeting and walking from the Braintree side of PMP.  One of the great things about walking at PMP is there are some shady areas along with some nice breezes once in awhile.  Let's meetup and get to know each other while walking around the pond!

We'll walk 1-2 loops today at a slow to moderate pace, possibly adding in the Weymouth entrance stretch. 1 loop plus that stretch will net us 2.5 miles in about 45-55 minutes.  2 loops will net us 3.5 miles in about 1 hr and 10-20 minutes, and 2 loops plus that stretch will net us 3.9 miles in about 1 hr and 15-30 minutes.  Therefore, we will most likely walk 1 loop plus that stretch.

Pond Meadow Park consists of a paved loop as well as paved walkways to and from both sets of parking lots.  This path is hilly with some flat terrain.  If you choose to head out into the woods the trails are marked but not paved.  The loop is 1.6 miles, with the walk to and from the parking lot it is 1.9 miles. It takes about 35-40 minutes to walk the loop. If we walk the loop twice it's a total of 3.5 miles and takes between 1 hr and 1 hr and 15 minutes, depending on pace. If we walk to the street of the Weymouth entrance it adds .4 miles and takes about 5-10 minutes.

A Few Items to Keep In Mind:

Your Yes RSVP means you will be attending and we are expecting you so please be courteous and change your RSVP prior to the RSVP deadline if you are no longer able to attend.

Pace: Today our walking speed will be approximately[masked]mph.  The first loop will be approximately[masked]mph for a leisurely pace for some and an average (or even fast) pace for others.  We will speed it up closer to[masked]mph on the 2nd loop for more of a fitness walk for most.  If a "slower" walker wants to co-host or lead a group on a "slower" pace for the 2nd loop then the[masked]mph speeds will be done together the first half of the first loop and then the fast walkers can speed up for the remaining 1&1/2 loops to[masked]mph and the slower walkers can maintain their pace.  *Please be respectful of our paces today.  I will keep us on pace and slow or speed us up periodically as needed.*

This is weather-dependent and is being held in conjunction w/ the South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club (SSHBSC) Meetup Group.  

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

Sunday Morning South Shore Spring Forward Walk @ Pond Meadow Park
Sunday, March 13th @ 10am
Pond Meadow Park
470 Liberty Street, Braintree
[masked]      
Website:  www.pondmeadowpark.org
Meeting Location: Flagpole in front of Ranger Station


Event Host(s)/Organizer(s): Leslie J & Angela

Min/Max: At least 6 Yes RSVPs 48 hours prior to the event. Attendance is currently unlimited.  (If the event does have a limit and reaches capacity, the WL is set to Automatic, meaning as a spot opens up the next person on the WL will automatically be moved to the Yes list.  Please be sure to change your RSVP if you are no longer able to attend.)

Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome.

Late Arrivals: We will wait our traditional 5-10 minutes for late arrivals.

Cost/Fees:  There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event.  PMP does have some donation bins if you so wish to do so.  If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 6pm on Saturday, March 12th.  Any changes made after this time may not be seen by an Event Organizer prior to the event and are subject to our No-Show policy.  The Event Organizer(s)/Host(s) reserves the right to cancel this event if we have less than 6 Yes RSVPs at the RSVP Deadline.  While we have access to our email to see any last-minute changes, the RSVP Deadline is when we print the RSVP List and is the last time I am on the website. (Note: You can RSVP up until 1 hour prior to the event @ 9am, however, we may not have you on our RSVP list - or your change - if you RSVP after the RSVP Deadline of 6pm on Sat 3/12.)

Inclement Weather: Heavy rains and/or temps below 45 will cancel. Please dress accordingly. (We will do our best to notify everyone if this event is cancelled by 8:30am on the day of the walk.)

Rain/Inclement Weather Date: None at this time as we will host more walks throughout the season.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Best directions should be taken from mapquest.com or maps.google.com. Located on Liberty Street, 500 feet from the intersection of Liberty and Middle Street near the Route 3 overpass directly across from Zana Park Drive.

Please note there is a rotary now instead of a regular intersection just before PMP.

From Route 3: Take Exit 17/Union St., Braintree. Exit on the side of the (Sunoco) Gas Station and Police Station. Follow Union Street to the first set of lights. Take a Right at the lights onto Middle Street. Follow about 1 mile to a Rotary. Go 3/4 of the way around the Rotary and exit onto Liberty Street. (This used to be a regular intersection where you took a left.) PMP is 500 feet up on the Right.
 


Parking: Free parking in 4 lots: lower lot immediately off Liberty Street, Upper lot inside gate which wraps around, and 2 lots further down closer to the trails which are past the first two parking lots (one is a grass lot on the right and the other is a paved lot on the left).  If it's before the park opens or is close to closing time then you can park on Zana Park Drive directly across from PMP.  Please be respectful of the neighbors; do not block driveways and park on ONE SIDE of the street.

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request. 

Hey, if you say you are going to attend please do.  If you find you are no longer able to attend please change your RSVP.  If you are unable to do that then please post on the event wall or message one of the Event Hosts/Organizers. This is especially important if the event is full and/or there is a Wait List.  It's the nice thing to do.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet by the flagpole in front of the Ranger Station.
results.name: Sunday Morning South Shore Spring Forward Walk @ Pond Meadow Park

results.description:
We will be working through Meyer text on the Dussack.  We will also look at how these techniques apply to  One-handed or arming sword.

We are going to interpret Joachim Meyer’s Dussak.  The translation we will use is in

The Art of Combat: A German Martial Arts Treatise of 1570 (Hardcover)

http://www.amazon.com/gp/offer-listing/1848327781/ref=sr_1_5_twi_2_har_olp?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1434813702&sr=1-5&keywords=meyer

with additional material from Meyer’s 1560 work

https://sites.google.com/site/jochimmeyer1560/home/Meyer_1560_english_Maurer_2012.pdf?attredirects=0&d=1

From Jakob Sutor’s “New Illustrated Fechtbuch” of 1612

https://docs.google.com/file/d/0Bxqzt-jcOCFsT19Xa1Q2QXltWm8/edit

Finally some from

Cod.Guelf.83.4 Aug.8º


http://www.thearma.org/Manuals/Codex-Guelf-83.4-Aug-8f-translation.pdf
results.name: Dussack, One-handed sword, Interpreting Mair Dussack

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

Sunday Morning South Shore Spring Forward Walk @ Pond Meadow Park 
Sunday, March 13th @ 10am 
Pond Meadow Park 
470 Liberty Street, Braintree 
[masked]      
Website:  www.pondmeadowpark.org 
Meeting Location: Flagpole in front of Ranger Station


Event Host(s)/Organizer(s): Angela & TBD (A co-host would be appreciated but is not required.  SF has a co-host.)

Min/Max: At least 6 Yes RSVPs 48 hours prior to the event. Attendance is currently unlimited.  (If the event does have a limit and reaches capacity, the WL is set to Automatic, meaning as a spot opens up the next person on the WL will automatically be moved to the Yes list.  Please be sure to change your RSVP if you are no longer able to attend.)

Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome.

Late Arrivals: We will wait our traditional 5-10 minutes for late arrivals.

Cost/Fees:  There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event.  PMP does have some donation bins if you so wish to do so.  If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 6pm on Saturday, March 12th. Any changes made after this time may not be seen by an Event Organizer prior to the event and are subject to our No-Show policy. The Event Organizer(s)/Host(s) reserves the right to cancel this event if we have less than 6 Yes RSVPs at the RSVP Deadline.  While we have access to our email to see any last-minute changes, the RSVP Deadline is when we print the RSVP List and is the last time I am on the website. (Note: You can RSVP up until 1 hour prior to the event @ 9am, however, we may not have you on our RSVP list - or your change - if you RSVP after the RSVP Deadline of 6pm on Sat 3/12.)

Inclement Weather: Heavy rains and/or temps below 45 will cancel. Please dress accordingly. (We will do our best to notify everyone if this event is cancelled by 8:30am on the day of the walk.)

Rain/Inclement Weather Date: None at this time as we will host more walks throughout the season.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

Directions: Best directions should be taken from mapquest.com or maps.google.com. Located on Liberty Street, 500 feet from the intersection of Liberty and Middle Street near the Route 3 overpass directly across from Zana Park Drive. 

Please note there is a rotary now instead of a regular intersection just before PMP. 

From Route 3: Take Exit 17/Union St., Braintree. Exit on the side of the (Sunoco) Gas Station and Police Station. Follow Union Street to the first set of lights. Take a Right at the lights onto Middle Street. Follow about 1 mile to a Rotary. Go 3/4 of the way around the Rotary and exit onto Liberty Street. (This used to be a regular intersection where you took a left.) PMP is 500 feet up on the Right. 
 

Parking: Free parking in 4 lots: lower lot immediately off Liberty Street, Upper lot inside gate which wraps around, and 2 lots further down closer to the trails which are past the first two parking lots (one is a grass lot on the right and the other is a paved lot on the left).  If it's before the park opens or is close to closing time then you can park on Zana Park Drive directly across from PMP.  Please be respectful of the neighbors; do not block driveways and park on ONE SIDE of the street. 

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request. 

Hey, if you say you are going to attend please do. If you find you are no longer able to attend please change your RSVP.  If you are unable to do that then please post on the event wall or message one of the Event Hosts/Organizers. This is especially important if the event is full and/or there is a Wait List.  It's the nice thing to do.

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs


Reality is known through reason


Meaning comes from making a difference


Human hands solve human problems


Be accepting, and be accepted

Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.

results.description:
We're hoping for an especially warm start to spring this year. Join us on Sunday, March 13th from 10AM to 3PM for our first Spring Work Party of the season to get all our boats splashed back into the Charles! 

We'll need all hands on board to help splash our Mercury boats into the water, place the masts onto the boats, rig them, and tune them. There'll be loads of hands-on work to do. It'll be fun and interactive - no prior experience necessary. 

***You don't need to be a member to volunteer, and you can feel free to bring as many friends as you'd like. You can ask as many questions about Community Boating and how membership works as you'd like and either other members or staff will be able to answer your questions. We'll also need help with a photo project indoors organizing and sorting photos.

Food, drinks, and snacks will be served. Drop on by for some exercise, fresh air, and good company.

Parking is available at nearby lot at Laz Parking next to Mass Eye and Ear Infirmary and the Charles/MGH circle. We can validate parking in our Front Office. The best way to Community Boating is by T - the closest stop is Charles/MGH on the Red Line. From there, you can cross the footbridge from Charles circle to the Esplanade. Community Boating is the first building in front.

If you can't make this Work Party, please save the date for our next Spring Work Party on Saturday, March 26th.

results.description:
Every Sunday at 10:30 AM we gather in our Sunday Circle, a time for gratitude,  prayer, song, and reflection.  Anyone is welcome to simply come as you are to any of these gatherings.  Please join us if you are seeking a time of centering, transformation, and connection with other people on their spiritual journeys. 

In the Sunday Circles we embody a rootedness in a Christian faith that is open to all faiths.  Our minister, Rev. Dr. Ian Mevorach, often preaches a dialogue sermon that invites the insights and wisdom of all who are gathered.   Other ministers, members of the community, or special guests also take turns leading our circles. Themes of spirituality, social and environmental justice, openness and love are at the core. We often engage in interfaith dialogue. We discuss scriptures from the Bible and other sacred texts, as well as explore poetry, music, and other sources of inspiration.  Every first Sunday of the month we celebrate an inclusive communion that is open to all.

Ou Sunday Circles are a time and place where people come together in a sacred way and where various threads in our community are often woven together into a greater whole.
results.how_to_find_us: Our building is located on Common Street overlooking the town green in Natick Center.  Parking in side and back lots.

results.description:
From http://www.meetup.com/Ethical-Society-of-Boston/events/228099750:

Leah Mickens is a Graduate Division of Religion, PhD student at Boston University

This talk will provide an overview of the humanist movement in the twentieth century, especially as it pertains to three crucial social justice movements: the abortion law repeal/decriminalization movement, the voluntary euthanasia movement, and the early movement for African American civil rights. Although the numbers of self-proclaimed humanists has always been relatively small, this talk will show how they were able to change American society in profound ways.

Given how the contemporary atheist movement has been bitterly divided about the role that social justice should play among the non-religious, it’s worth remembering that freethinking traditionally has had a very strong ethical component that involved questioning the status quo and the hierarchies associated with it. If a lack of belief in god or the demise of traditional religion leads to the same systems of exploitation, racism, sexism, and homophobia that currently exists, what’s the point? Humanism and its strong tradition of social justice are what is needed to prevent “mere atheism” from becoming just another philosophical club for the comfortable and privileged.

Daylight Savings Time starts this weekend. Remember to set your clocks ahead.
results.name: Ethical Society Boston: Creative Minority Report: How Humanists Changed America

results.description:
Join us on court this Sunday at 11 a.m. for the start of this spring season's Beginner Level Group Tennis Clinics conducted by highly experience tennis professionals.


This weekly (every Sunday) series of group clinics is a 6-session, 9 hour (each session runs 90 minutes) series of clinics designed for beginner level tennis players.

The fundamentals of tennis will be covered throughout the series in a format that will utilize precise tennis drills and clear description of fundamentally correct tennis technique to reinforce these tennis essentials with each participating player.

Each 90-minute session in the series will include: warm-up exercises; dynamic stretching; cardio drills; skill-building tennis drills; description and demonstration of fundamentally sound tennis strokes.

Each participant will get to hit many balls during drills under the watchful eye of the supervising tennis pro.

We have priced this series of clinics at the handsomely discounted, cost-friendly rate of just $135. That averages a very low $15/hr/player.

Learn the game of tennis or improve your beginner level strokes. In these clinics, you'll do just that and, at the same time, increase your enjoyment of tennis.

Make this the year you take your tennis game to the next level!

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
India Castle 928 Massachusetts Ave  Cambridge, MA  (Between Central SQ  and Harvard SQ)  Phone (617)[masked] website cambridgeindiacastle.com

Let's enjot  a Lunch  Buffet at India Castle in Cambridge, MA

 I've eaten here 3 times before and it been tasty and only 8.95!  The curries had a similar taste to all of them but overall they were good for an all you can eat buffet at that price. The samosas were very good  too(better than other buffets) and I was happy that they had dessert (rice pudding and gulab jamun).  The chicken tikka masala, naan (chewy, not
overly buttered; perfect) and tandoori chicken were all good too. I’ve seen them switch from a  had mango juice to a milk Tea which I've never seen included in a buffet price. Overall, I good and affordable!

Seriously a Buffet for only $8.95 is great…try it and you'll
see what I mean. It’s not the best Indian food in the Boston, but its very good
and you can’t beat an all you can eat buffet for  only $8.95!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for and then ask for Biagio inside

results.description:
Hi Soccer Comrades! 

The weather Sunday is predicted to be sunny and pleasant and (about 54° fahrenheit / 12 °celsius).  Please come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 12:00 noon.  We will do this at the turf field of Belmont High School, as we have in recent weeks. A few things to remember:

This is the "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.

Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy.  Please wear shin guards. This is a friendly game but we want to avoid accidental injuries. Cleats are recommended.

Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather.

You can find the location at Google Maps with the link: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.39523,-71.1674112,17z

The turf field is located just to the right of the Viglirolo Skating Rink

Let's enjot  a Lunch  Buffet at India Castle in Cambridge, MA

I've eaten here 3 times before and it been tasty and only 8.95!  The curries had a similar taste to all of them but overall they were good for an all you can eat buffet at that price. The samosas were very good  too(better than other buffets) and I was happy that they had dessert (rice pudding and gulab jamun).  The chicken tikka masala, naan (chewy, not
overly buttered; perfect) and tandoori chicken were all good too. I’ve seen them switch from a  had mango juice to a milk Tea which I've never seen included in a buffet price. Overall, I good and affordable!

Seriously a Buffet for only $8.95 is great…try it and you'll
see what I mean. It’s not the best Indian food in the Boston, but its very good
and you can’t beat an all you can eat buffet for  only $8.95!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for and then ask for Biagio inside

results.description:
In celebration of Women’s History Month, the Freedom Trail Foundation announces a first-time ever opportunity to experience and discover the women who took part in the American Revolution, and the generations of women that followed, inaugurating their own struggles for freedom and equality.

The official pilot of the new Freedom Trail Revolutionary Women Tour invites people of all ages to walk the Freedom Trail and explore four centuries of Revolutionary Women who changed history. This 90-minute tour will feature tales of the early religious rebellions of Anne Hutchinson and Mary Dyer, patriotic actions of Abigail Adams and Mercy Otis Warren, abolitionist movements of Harriet Beecher Stowe and Harriet Tubman, prolific writings of authors Phillis Wheatley and Louisa May Alcott, and landmark speeches of Margaret Sanger and Susan B. Anthony, while visiting the places where women’s voices were heard, their works published, and women were laid to rest along Boston’s iconic red line.

The Revolutionary Women Tour departs from the Boston Common Visitor Information Center.

To purchase tickets online please go to:
https://www.thefreedomtrail.org/ftf-thundertix.html
results.how_to_find_us: At the ticket booth.
results.name: Revolutionary Women Tours on The Freedom Trail

results.description:
Faith, Family & Freedom In Early Jewish America featuring Historian Keith Stokes 

 Sunday, March 13 at 1:00 PM

Vilna Shul, 18 Phillips Street, Beacon Hill

Free and open to the public. RSVP appreciated at vilnashul.org.

History buffs and genealogists rejoice! Join us for a riveting historical narrative that recounts the Jewish settlement in early America between 1665 and 1865 through the experiences of the Hays, Touro and Myers families.  Beginning in the 17th century in New York and Newport, Rhode Island, these extended families continued to evolve as Jewish Americans into 19th century Boston, New Orleans and Richmond, Virginia.  Discover how these Jewish families are actively involved with many of the most historic places and events in American history, including the American Revolution and Civil War. Discounted parking is available for $5 with validation at the Charles River Garage.

More info at vilnashul.org
results.name: Faith, Family & Freedom In Early Jewish America featuring Historian Keith Stokes

results.description:
For many of us, one of the best things about living life according to humanist values is that there's no one right path, no set mold we need to fit in terms of what success and meaning need to look like. Still, even nonreligious people can experience great pressure to follow the path that seems expected of us-- by our parents, our peers, or ourselves.

Certainly we are right to expect one another to live up to the standard of basic ethical decency. And it may be a good thing to encourage one another to take standards for ethical living even beyond the basics-- maybe it's fine if there's a little peer pressure show compassion to others, to do what we can to protect the environment, or to help promote racial, gen

der, or other forms of social justice. But even within that framework, life offers more possibilities than we often realize. We can fail in a big way, then succeed later. We can completely change our careers, or our personal lives, or both. We can overcome aspects of our personalities that don't work for us, and we can learn to accept parts of ourselves that we never could before. In short: we can evolve as human beings, sometimes dramatically. 

Back in December, Greg Epstein devoted his monthly talk at The Humanist Hub to curating a session where Hub members and friends shared their own dramatic personal stories of "Courage in Dark Times." This month, he'll once again lead a session, inspired by The Moth and other storytelling traditions, where some of the people whose life journeys (thus far) have inspired him share their own stories. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to have a second act in life (or a third, or fourth, or more!) join us for this session exploring what it is like for secular people to envision ourselves, at times, as a phoenix rising from ashes.

Join Humanist Chaplain Greg Epstein for his monthly talk: with music, food, discussion circles, and more.
results.name: Greg Epstein: The Phoenix as a Humanist Symbol

results.description:
This event pertains to the general beekeeping community, and is not an official BABA event. This event is hosted by Beelieve, a $10 donation is suggested.

Dan Conlon, owner of Warm Colors Apiary in South Deerfield, Western Mass., and Vice President of the Russian Honey Bee Breeders Association (RHBA), will present on what is going on with honey bee genetics, what impact the loss of genetic diversity has on our bee populations, and what queen breeders and researchers are doing about it. Dan will review how honey bee breeders select for the best Queens, what criteria they value in the selection process, and how finding disease resistance and mite tolerance requires large numbers of colonies to find and maintain desirable behaviors. He will review how the RHBA breeding program is working at Warm Colors and how backyard beekeepers can benefit by raising their own queens.
results.name: Honey Bee Genetics and Breeding

results.description:
Scattered throughout New England's wood, waters and backyards are hundreds of stone features left behind by earlier generations of New Englanders. Besides the familiar abandoned farmsteads and field walls, there are more enigmatic features: stone chambers, cairns, rows, U-shapes, rocking stones, petroglyphs and perched boulders . At times ascribed to farmers, Indians, Irish monks, Vikings, Phonecians, Templars, and natural forces , perhaps the only thing they all have in common is that few can agree on who made them, when, and for what purpose . In this presentation, we will visit a number of such lithic sites in Massachusetts and neighboring states, present theories of their origin, and explore why they remain so controversial.
Peter Anick is the state coordinator for NEARA , the New England Antiquities Research Association , a group dedicated to the documentation and study of regional lithic site.. A professional computer scientist and volunteer archaeologist, Peter strives to balance keeping an open mind with the need for scientific objectivity
results.name: Join us for a Presentation on Ancient Ruins in New England

results.description:
This event is posed with multiple meetups for informational purposes.

Johnny D's in Davis Square Somerville opened in 1969 and is closing on March 13, 2016!  Thank you to the Johnny D's Family for all your decades of hard work, great shows and entertaining nights out.

 If you are free the afternoon of March 13 arrive early for the Closing Ceremonies. Expect a line.

Doors open at 4:00pm.

Cost is Free. All ages are welcome.

Kitchen is closed.

Two short sets by the Second Line Social Aide and Pleasure Society Brass Band

and The Revolutionary Snake Ensamble

5:30pm Procession Parade through Davis Square

Doors to Johnny D's closed forever.

Schedule subject to change.

Check with Johnny D's on line for updates.
results.name: Johnny D's Closing Ceremonies 4:00pm on Sunday March 13

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Potbelly Sandwich Shop behind CVS (on Somerville Ave) 

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. You can easily spot Potbelly Sandwich Shop on side entrance when you arrive at top of escalator at Porter Square Station. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

From Johnny D's:

Sunday March 13,  Second Line Brass Band Parade is not to be missed. Come march with us into Davis Square from Johnny D’s, locking the doors behind us. Doors open into Johnny D’s at 4pm ALL AGES for 2 short sets by Revolutionary Snake Ensemble and Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society Brass Band. At 5:30 the procession will start. (Kitchen is not open for service)

"On Sunday March 13, 5:30 pm please JOIN us for our PARADE with some great marching bands including Revolutionary Snake Ensemble and Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society Brass Band. Yes, we will parade in the streets of Davis as a celebration and ending service of this awesome place. We would be most honored if you joined us!!"


Join our Second Line on our Final Day Show Details When: Sunday, Mar 13, 2016 5:30 PM (Doors open at 4:00 PM)Ticket Price: $0.00Door Time: 4:00 PMRevolutionary Snake Ensemble:"Sly funky tuneful avant garde jazz." - New York Music Daily


"They've pretty much modernized the traditional concept, and they've spun it into a singular sound that's very unique and very vibrant. They accelerated the norm. They went past the tried and true. They managed to do it all with a very distinct musical persona." - NPR's Morning Edition/Glenn Astarita The Revolutionary Snake Ensemble is a costumed funk/street beat improvisational brass band performing a unique blend of original and traditional music. Leader Ken Field is a longtime member of the modern music ensemble Birdsongs of the Mesozoic. Their latest release, "Live Snakes" (Accurate Records 2014), was recorded in 2011 and 2013 in Boston, Brooklyn, & Manhattan, and documents four distinct incarnations of the highly mutable ensemble, with two sonically inventive remixes by Field thrown in for good measure. Adding to the deep pool of Boston talent that has sustained the RSE for more than two decades, "Live Snakes" features an extended family of players, including New Orleans tenor saxophone great Charles Neville and New York masters Josh Roseman (trombone), Kenny Wollesen (drums & percussion), and Matt Darriau (tenor sax & flute).

Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society Brass Band:The Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society Brass Band is a 30 piece “raucous, stomp-your-foot-and-belt-out-the-choruses” New Orleans-style street band, based in Somerville and Cambridge, Massachusetts. We combine music with social action, slamming out the sounds of the legendary Crescent City for peace rallies, street festivals, parades, and benefits. We are also a part of the organizing force behind HONK!, a festival of activist street bands that takes place every October in Somerville’s Davis Square.


We thank you all for being the greatest customers and supporters ever, and we look forward to celebrating and bidding a proper farewell with you all!!

I think Queen had it right with this little tune.....

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AHWLVxg8MxA

results.description:
"Join our Second Line Brass Parade on Sun, March 13 - our Final Day

When: Sunday, Mar 13,[masked]:30 PM (Doors open at 4:00 PM)
Ticket Price: $0.00
Door Time: 4:00 PM

What a better way to celebrate 47 years but with a New Orlean's style Brass Band Parade as funeral procession of sorts. Our doors will open at 4pm for entrance where we will have 2 short sets from each of our local, awesome brass bands Revolutionary Snake Ensemble and Second Line Social Aid and Pleasure Society. Then we begin the procession out our doors, into Davis Square, locking the doors behind us and finishing with a gathering out in Statue Park across from the Somerville Theater. All ages are welcome. First 500 people get a Johnny D's imprinted Second line Hankerchief to wave as we parade! This will be a memory for a lifetime and it would mean so much to us if you came along our last journey.


Johnny D's greatness is a culmination of all of us. We thank you all for being the best customers and supporters ever and we look forward to celebrating and bidding a proper farewell with you!!

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

http://atwys2016bostonspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.description:
Sun 03/13/2016, 5:00 pm - 6:15 pm


Have you ever thought about detoxing your emotions?

Jealousy, guilt, anger, sadness… emotions pile up, and get clogged up. When we don’t find a way to release emotions that aren’t doing us any favours, they can drain or block our energy and stop us from thriving. As emotions affect every area of our life, from health and relationships to the workplace – come and explore with us ways to flush out all the toxins. Then you’ll feel clearer and lighter, and enhance your emotional health, vitality and stability.

Join us for tips on how to do an emotional detox.

We will discuss various techniques and ways of using them in your everyday life. You will have the opportunity to ask questions and practice guided meditation.

This event is led by Emilia Sabatowska who is a psychotherapist with an extensive training in Mindfulness Meditation. For more info, please go to: www.whole-living-center.com

results.description:
"Knight of Cups" opens this week at the Kendall.  We'll take in the 5:05 showing on Sunday.  Some synopses and other info follows.  Hope to see you at the movies!

Knight of Cups follows writer Rick (Christian Bale, The Fighter, American Hustle) on an odyssey through the playgrounds of Los Angeles and Las Vegas as he undertakes a search for love and self. Even as he moves through a desire-laden landscape of mansions, resorts, beaches and clubs, Rick grapples over complicated relationships with his brother (Wes Bentley) and father (Brian Dennehy). His quest to break the spell of his disenchantment takes him on a series of adventures with six alluring women: rebellious Della (Imogen Poots); his physician ex-wife, Nancy (Cate Blanchett); a serene model Helen (Freida Pinto); a woman he wronged in the past Elizabeth (Natalie Portman); a spirited, playful stripper Karen (Teresa Palmer); and an innocent Isabel (Isabel Lucas), who helps him see a way forward. Rick moves in a daze through a strange and overwhelming dreamscape -- but can he wake up to the beauty, humanity and rhythms of life around him? The deeper he searches, the more the journey becomes his destination. The 7th film from director Terrence Malick (The Thin Red Line, Tree of Life), Knight of Cups (the title refers to the Tarot card depicting a romantic adventurer guided by his emotions) offers both a vision of modern life and an intensely personal experience of memory, family, and love. Knight of Cups is produced by Nicolas Gonda, Sarah Green and Ken Kao. Prominent crew includes cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki (Gravity, Birdman), production designer Jack Fisk, costume designer Jacqueline West, and composer Hanan Townshend (To The Wonder). The film's ensemble cast also includes Antonio Banderas, Cherry Jones and Armin Mueller-Stahl.

Synopsis

A Hollywood screenwriter (Christian Bale) wanders around Los Angeles and Las Vegas while reflecting on his life of excess and connection to the natural world. At the same time, he struggles to bond with his brother (Wes Bentley) and father (Brian Dennehy), and has a series of love affairs with the women who drift in and out of his life. Terrence Malick directed this lyrical character study, which co-stars Natalie Portman, Cate Blanchett, Imogen Poots, and Teresa Palmer. ~ Daniel Gelb, Rovi

Just so you know....this has not garnered the best of reviews on Rotten Tomatoes.   It's fluctuated between 45-55.  But... I like the director and the cast...so I'm seeing it no matter what!
results.how_to_find_us: After the movie, we'll meet briefly up near the screen on the right, and then move quickly to the base of the stairs in the lobby (near the ticket takers) so folks can use the restrooms. Then we'll trek over to Cambridge Brewing for discussion.
results.name: Knight of Cups @Kendall Sunday 3/13  at 5:05pm

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 3/13 5:30

results.description:
Reserved seating is first come first seated.

About John Harvards: they brew their own beer, the brewery is visible behind the bar counter. They offer beer samplers ("flights") of six of their beers of 4oz. each. Why so generous (for 8$ )? Cause there's always one beer you just won't like.  Waitstaff is friendly and patient. Please pay as you go!

http://eapoe.org/WORKS/tales/crowdd.htm

What would people do without "the crowd"?

In America, people drink coffee in the morning. In the UK, there is "tea time". Why do people copy each other?

Nobody wears jeans with patches anymore. Unless they are intentionally ripped at the knee level and don't have a patch. People even pay extra for ripped jeans like that.

Why do people all face in the same direction when the subway is entering the platform? To make the subway arrive faster? Why do peeps want or think they want all the same things?  Like, everyone wants to be thin. Now, if we were a society of "fat" people would everyone strive to be pudgy? 

When somebody says, "I love classical music" is it because they really do, or is it because they think they are supposed to?

Without creativity, nothing would have developed in society, however, despite the myth of individualism, creativity is really not encouraged, so it seems. Imitation is. 

Please wear your most notorious fake mustaches. This event with Nerd Fun is nearing 50 Intellectual Snob events and thanks to Nerd Fun! and its intellectual curiosity.

results.description:
“Each of us is several, is many, is a profusion of selves. So that the self who disdains his surroundings is not the same as the self who suffers or takes joy in them. In the vast colony of our being there are many species of people who think and feel in different ways.” --from The Book of Disquiet

Fernando Pessoa [masked]) the brilliant Portuguese modernist might be the most eccentric writer you've never heard of.  His name, "Pessoa," means "person" in Portuguese, yet significantly, he thought of identity as a flexible, dynamic construction, which led him to reject the traditional notions of  individuality and authorship. So, he maintained multiple careers, as publisher, poet, translator, critic, and essayist, disguising his identity with more than seventy heteronyms, each possessing its own backstory and literary style. One invented writer was a doctor and classicist; a second was an unlettered genius, a paesano who lived in the country; a third was a naval engineer and bisexual dandy who traveled the world. A fourth was "Fernando Pessoa"...another was "Álvaro de Campos"...then there was "Ricardo Reis"...and so on.

So, where to begin? I recommend you dip into The Book of Disquiet, without trying to get to the end of it. It's a diary of insight, disquiet, and contradictions. There is nothing else like it. I'm also recommending a few readings below. Feel free to bring other poems or excerpts from this body of work to read and discuss.

A short excerpt from The Book of Disquiet (scroll to the bottom):

http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105106824

Odes by Ricardo Reis:

http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poetrymagazine/poem/15984

Autopsychography by Fernando Pessoa:

http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poetrymagazine/poem/15983

“So many gods!” by Álvaro de Campos:

http://www.poetryfoundation.org/poetrymagazine/poem/185257
results.name: Pessoa: The Book of Disquiet + Poetry

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>

results.description:
This webinar is targeted to current -- and future -- PGN leaders.  


It details the mechanics of actually creating an offering on PGN. (A separate orientation deals with the rationale, philosophy, strategy, and practicalities of becoming a leader in the personal growth community.)

For Whom Is This Webinar

This event is open to any PGN member who may be interested in creating an event on PGN:

Social Events
- dances; house parties
- socials; get-togethers; reunions
- dining; coffee; cocktails
- movies
- hiking; bungee jumping; ropes course
- games; bowling

Practice Groups
- Interest groups 
- Support groups
- Mastermind groups 
- Book clubs;
- Study groups

Workshops
- Presentations; classes; webinars; 
- MiniWorkshops; workshops; seminars;
- Retreats; longitudinal (multi-week, multi-month)

The Orientation Series

It is useful, but not necessary, to know the information provided in these orientations:
- Newbie Introduction to the Personal Growth Network
- User's Guide to the Personal Growth Network

This orientation may be taken in conjunction with
- Introduction to Leadership on PGN

This orientation is useful for more advanced leadership orientations, including:
- Creating/Introducing a Brand on PGN 
- Maximizing the Impact of your PGN Event
- Intro to Hosting a Heartbeat Salon

For seasoned leaders, using a new medium can be a bit confusing initially.  PGN's new paradigm allows a longer-term, win-win-win, mutually supportive approach, however, it also requires establishing some new habits.

For potential leaders, any PGN member thinking about offering something to other PGN members can find PGN a very empowering vehicle.  The orientations help you to effectively interface with the PGN toolbox, support, and community.

A Bit About Leadership on PGN

Personal growth leaders, who are members of PGN, offer over 200 events a year.  

One of the main goals of the Personal Growth Network is to identify, nurture, and support those leaders who have the ability and interest to create personal growth events for others.   Any member of PGN may utilize PGN to offer an event to the personal growth community.  Share your journey, your gifts, your joy, your successes, your vision, or your interests with like-hearted PGN members.

PGN offers such leaders a toolbox of software, of coaching, and of support to help them create successful events that benefit themselves and the PGN membership.

Scope

This guide will cover: 

- Timing
- Branding
- Titling
- Scoping
- Targeting
- Seeding
- Writing copy 
- Communicating
- Style notes

Please RSVP, and the webinar information will be sent to you.

Please also note any questions you may have below so that I may address them.

This is another event in our mid-winter indoor program to stay warm. This workshop needs everyone to participate: we will show our light painting tools and how to make and modify them.

This event is for paid members only. It is strongly recommended that you attend the lecture on light painting prior to this event.


This is a hands-on demo with all of us going upfront and demonstrating what modifications you did to your light painting tools or what tools you came up with from scratch. I will show LED strips, Sherrie will introduce you to colandria, Lisa will show off with her latest colored protector tube, Devora has some LED bundles to show and Jackie will introduce us to her expensive Emazing Lights tool. There is no restrictions on what we can bring and demo.


Please also bring exotic light painting tools that you found somewhere, and it would be great if you could give us the source where you got it from and how much it cost. We will compile a list and distribute it to everyone.


We will also discuss the following topics:

• Flashlights: what types there are and what to look for. How many lumens?


• Snoots: how to focus flashlights: hands-on demo on how to make snoots with tips on the material. We can do this a few times, I will have some materials to practice.

• Other light modifiers such as deflectors, grids etc.

• LED strips and how to use them as light painting tools


• YOUR favorite light painting tools on display. Please bring your tools that you made or modified for others to see.


• Pointers on how to modify camera exposure to get the most out of your tools. But I encourage you to attend the lecture on light painting and there may be another lecture by Lance on the history of light painting and deconstruction of some contemporary work.

Do you need more leads and are struggling to get meetings and sales from your emails?
