results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
From 5-6pm attendee's will have an opportunity to test out the Push 2 and get a feel for the new sampling workflows. Ben Casey and Mmmmaven Instructor, Wigbert Caro will show attendees around the new hardware.

Then, from 6-7pm Ben Casey will discuss The Push 2. The new Push is designed and engineered entirely by Ableton, with hands-on sampling workflows, a large multicolour display and softer, more expressive pads. Live 9.5 boasts new analog-modeled filters, new waveforms and metering displays, and new sampling capabilities. Ableton Certified Trainer Ben Casey will be at Mmmaven to show off these new features and more. Plus we’ll introduce Link – a new technology that syncs devices’ timing over a wireless network.

Ben Casey is a Brooklyn-based electronic musician, Ableton Certified Trainer, and overall music tech nerd. When he’s not surrounded by wires and drum machines or tinkering with Max for Live, Ben teaches Ableton Live to musicians across all genres, from avant-garde to zydeco. While living in London he earned an MMUS from Goldsmiths University, and released tracks on the inscrutable UK-based label Werkdiscs. A Live user since its very beginning, Ben is always happy to show off his boxed copy of Version 1. He works with Grammy-winning artists to integrate Live into their existing production and performance workflows, consulting on numerous live tours, theater productions, and art installations.

results.description:
This meetup is rescheduled from last month. I hope everyone can join. Here's the description:

This month, we will focus on building relationships with step-children. Some step-parents have it easier than others in getting along with step-kids but most step-parents face some struggles along the way. These challenges can stem from your step-child's difficulty in accepting you as their parent's partner, or ambiguity about your step-parent role (step-parents can feel like a hybrid of a parent and babysitter). Other difficulties stem from an absence of the shared history and bond, developmental challenges for your step-child or simply personality differences. Members are encouraged to share their challenges and successes.
results.name: Improving Relationships with Your Step-Kids

results.description:
Please come and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in Panera Bread, located in the Fresh Pond mall, about a 10 minute walk from Alewife station. The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play.

This meetup is officially canceled unless at least five sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.

results.description:
Discover the holistic benefits of the Feldenkrais Method®!

Each 90 minute Awareness Through Movement class consists of guided attention through carefully sequenced movements that are designed to stimulate your curiosity, challenge your coordination, and bring you into a new way of being in both body and mind.


By encouraging us to slow down, reduce effort, and delve into the building blocks of our movement, Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement enables us to discover previously unnoticed areas of habitual tension and unlock new possibilities for moving freely.  Come and experience for yourself what an effective resource it can be for stress relief, improving balance and posture, and alleviating chronic pain at the source. 

Classes are open to adults at all fitness levels. No prior experience necessary.  

Drop-ins are welcome, but RSVPing will give you the opportunity to influence the content of the class for your needs and interests!
results.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement® class!

results.description:
New:

Due to time constraints and the game being very adjustable to new players joining and leaving at any time, I am making a change.

I do wish people to get something to compensate IHOP for letting us use the space, however, if you have not started or finished eating by 7:15pm please, start or finish eating at another table. The rest of the people will clean the table and start playing.  I want the rest of the players to have a chance to finish a game.


The rules give new players the opportunity to join the game at the start of any new hand, with the score of the mean player.

I am trying to keep the game and conversation balanced for everyone.  If multiple players are eating, conversing and playing,  the game may be held up until some people are restless.

Also, the more people eating and playing while handling the cards, the greater chance the few decks of "Jumbo Index" cards used for Negation Hearts will be marked and hard to shuffle, detracting from the game.

As always, please put your cold drinks on a napkin.

Thank you;

Negation Hearts Night. New players are VERY welcome: We will teach you how to play.

It is suggested that you get a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment. .

PUBLIC:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have nearby stops. 

Negation Hearts is played with two decks of cards. Two of the same cards like two king of clubs negate and the next highest card of the suit lead takes the cards played. So, even playing a two has not been safe at times. The scoring and passing are slightly altered from "Cancellation" hearts so that new people can join in or leave at the start of any hand.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced between the two.
results.name: Negation Hearts in Salem @ IHOP *

Work along to get started using Aurelia.  


We'll give a brief update on Aurelia state of the union and an overview of Aurelia features.  We'll then get started with installing the standard Aurelia Navigation Skeleton and adding a couple of pages to get you started using Aurelia.


If we have time after that, we will host a project/Q&A session.


If you already know Aurelia, please join us and give people a hand with their first Aurelia website and for the project/Q&A session. 

Agenda:

6:30-6:45 - Start downloading Aurelia if needed (please try to have Node.js and gulp installed  ('npm install -g gulp' beforehand)

6:30-7:00 - Pizza and soft drinks courtesy of Selventa

7:00-8:00 - Quick overview of Aurelia, install Aurelia Skeleton, add a page, discuss starter topics (devtools, help sources, etc)

8:00 - Questions/Project discussion

SECURITY: All guests must register with building security, located in the lobby of One Memorial Drive, prior to entering Microsoft’s facility. Everyone must present a government issued, photo ID to lobby security in order to be allowed access to the building. If a Meetup participant is unable to present the proper ID, they will not be allowed access to the building. 


PARKING INFORMATION: Meetup participants are allowed to park in our garage located at One Memorial Drive. All day parking is $27.00 on weekdays and $10.00 on weekends. Please note that these rates are subject to change.

results.description:
March 14, 2016 Presentation - our speaker(s) have changed:

Our March speakers, IANE members Chloe Hill and Darryl Yang, are co-founders of Hypnap LLC, a start-up company based out of Boston, MA with a mission to create elegant, high-quality products that facilitate comfort, relaxation and well-being. Hypnap is excited about bringing a unique solution to the market that truly benefits people and provides real comfort to airplane passengers on their flights and beyond.

  Tired of assuming body positions worthy of Cirque de Soleil contortionists while trying to get comfortable on your flight? Frustrated with arriving at your destination exhausted and in pain? Hypnap TruRest has created a solution and finally made deep rest achievable on your airplane flight. Ergonomically designed, Hypnap TruRest is the first travel sleep aid that supports the user in a face down, forward leaning position, rendering seat recline unnecessary, and facilitating more comfort and relaxation on airplane flights.

  Designed for airplane passengers but appropriate for anyone with access to a table top or desk top surface, Hypnap TruRest sits on the tray table and is collapsible, lightweight and portable for easy carriage. Hypnap TruRest is also elegantly designed making it a pleasure to use and be seen with.

  In addition, it’s not just for snoozing. The breathing cavity is large enough for the user to have a clear view so that one can read or do work while using the TruRest.

  Photos of the current prototype are on Hypnap’s Twitter page at www.twitter.com/hypnap <http://www.twitter.com/hypnap>;. For more, see Hypnap’s elegant website at  www.hypnap.com <http://www.hypnap.com/>; Chloe and Darryl also have presented at the IANE Inventors Clinic.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait 5-10 minutes for people to show, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.

(NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in the middle of the block.
results.name: Light Game Night @ Cosi (Monday)

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.


2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, if you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.



OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Monday Game Night

results.description:
Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.

Michael Skubisz, VP of Product Management at Deep Information Sciences, will discuss the challenges, limitations and options available to wring the most out of MySQL and avoid the costly re-architecting of your database system.

Michael is a senior executive manager with more than 25 years of experience. He has a strong history in technology companies and is well versed in the challenges faced by both start up companies as well as established Fortune 500 companies. He has experience across multiple industries including database, enterprise data communications, telecommunications access equipment and OSS and network management software. Michael has long been a technology innovator and holds 9 U.S. Patents.

results.description:
PJ Ryan's is celebrating St. Paddy's Day early this Monday 3/14 with some tasty IPAs from some amazing breweries! Jack's Abby, Stone, Smuttynose and Brooklyn will each be bringing a tasty IPA for you to try and compare, so come get some beers and don't forget to wear green! RSVP and details here: 

Try a Pataskala Red X IPA brewed with a new variety of German malt called Red X and then dry hopped, this beer has a a citrus packed hop punch followed by biscuit and toffee notes.

 Jack's Abby Big Red Mitch is a new Red India Pale Lager that has an assertive hop packed flavor. This one is hard to find outside of the brewpub, so make sure you give it a shot!

Sip on a Bitter Oats is a big boozy blonde that was brewed with a boatload of oats, giving it a creamy, sweet mouthfeel with a hoppy blast.

Cast your vote with your dollar, or be a true beer fantastic and try one of each! Whatever your strategy, make sure you don't miss out on the start to a very hoppy St. Paddy's day! RSVP to save a spot. This event is free to attend, pay as you drink.

They'll be serving some fantastic beers.

Pataskala

India Pale Ale (IPA) - 7.3%

This beer is named after Stone co-founder Greg Koch's hometown of Pataskala, Ohio. Brewed with a new German malt variety called "Red X" and dry hopped with Mosaic, Cascade, and Amarillo- this beer is incredibly citrus-forward, rounded out with biscuit and toffee notes.

The Defender

India Pale Ale (IPA) - 6.7%

THE DEFENDER is constantly vigilant, standing guard over all those who dare to create, to dream, and to drink great beer. This bright, juicy, West Coast-style IPA takes on a reddish twist from a dash of roasted malt. Bold, fruity hop bitterness and an intensely resinous nose lead the way into a dry finish that blazes the trail for your next sip. Brooklyn Defender IPA was forged in collaboration with our sidekicks at New York Comic Con as the official beer of the convention.

Jack's Abby Big Red Mitch

Lager - 7.2%

This Imperial Red Lager is a wicked hoppy blend of Cimcoe, Amarillo, Centennial, and Idaho-7 hops designed to make you sit up and take notice. Named after one of our favorite salesmen who may have grown out his red hair, but he'll always be a ginger to us!

Finest Kind IPA

American IPA - 6.9% 75 IBUs

Finestkind IPA is a physical salute to the glory of the American hop grower. The citrusy hop flavor coming from a mixture of Simcoe and Santiams is pleasantly balanced by a smooth bitterness from the Amarillo hops. The beer itself is light bodied and crisp with a golden color that will throw a slight haze, as we bottle it unfiltered. At 75 IBU's, this is definitely not a training-wheels IPA, but is meant for hop lovers looking to satisfy their craving in a way that's not easy to find.

Bitter Oats

American Double IPA - 10.5%

2016 OneHitter Series. This big boozy blonde was brewed with a boatload of oats, giving it a creamy, sweet mouthfeel with a hoppy blast. It's like a powdered sugar doughnut topped with deliciously bitter, danky resinous hops. Chow down!
results.name: Hoppy St Paddy's Day-Jack's Abby, Stone, Lagunitas, Smuttynose & Brooklyn!

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
The Buddhist Study & Meditation Group will meet every Monday at 8pm at the Common Street Spiritual Center in Natick. Please use the School Street entrance. If you go to the top floor, we are down the hall on the left, in the meditation room.

If you have your own cushion, please feel free to bring it. Otherwise, chairs and floor seats are provided. The term mindfulness has become part of our everyday language, we talk about "eating mindfully", or "trying to be more mindful in our consumer choices." Furthermore, the actual method of Mindfulness is taught in prisons and schools to reduce stress, it is taught by cognitive therapists to modify dysfunctional patterns of behavior, and it is practiced by corporate CEOs to enhance effectiveness in the workplace. In other words, we have co-opted mindfulness. We have extracted it from its original context and striped it of soteriological meaning. Worse, it has been turned into an elixir to promote the smooth functioning of our most destructive institutions. The word mindfulness comes from the Pali term sati and it is part of the eightfold path which the Buddha prescribed to end Dhaka, the stressful and disturbing mental constructions through which we view ourselves and others. Mindfulness, in this context, is the basis for insight into the true nature of reality, and according to the Buddhist tradition, when we "wake up" to the true nature of things, we realize that we are not in as bad shape as we thought. It's likened to waking up from a bad dream. Buddha is said to have become awakened through practicing mindfulness of the breath. In our weekly meetings we will practice basic mindfulness meditation and we will seek to understand how this practice fits within the framework of the Buddha's teachings. Each meeting will last about an hour and consist of brief meditation exercises and some discussion of the Buddha's radical approach to life.
results.name: Meditate and discuss the Buddha's teachings

Monday March 14, Brian Glowacki headlines Cityside Comedy Club

Brian Glowacki is a stand up comedian from the mean streets of Nantucket, Massachusetts. Growing up on a sandbar in the middle of the ocean has given him a unique perspective on the world around him. His fun, lighthearted humor is a refreshing change of pace in a world full of angry bosses, burnt dinners, and road rage. Brian is able to transition seamlessly from picking on himself to dissecting the shortcomings of the human race. He welcomes you into his home through stories of his family, his failed relationships, and his interactions with some interesting characters he's met along the way. Brian tours the country in search of fun audiences, buffet dinners, and dependable Wi-Fi. Check him out at a show near you.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Register for this FREE webinar at: http://app.webinarjam.net/register/3004/ea03fe7120


In this presentation you will discover:

1- How to build an active and fast growing meetup group

2- How to find amazing speakers and expand your personal network

3- How to position yourself as an authority in your field in a short time by running a networking group

You've probably been to many meetups, now see behind the scenes of running a successful networking group.

Register for this FREE webinar at: http://app.webinarjam.net/register/3004/ea03fe7120


Iman Aghay is the founder of Entrepreneurs Global Network, a fast growing network for entrepreneurs to learn, network and grow with local chapters across the globe from Vancouver, BC to Perth, Australia.

Iman built his business absolutely from scratch by creating one of the fastest growing business networks in the world and ever since has been working and consulting with other networks to help them grow faster and attract more qualified members.

In this presentation he will show you how to:

results.description:
Mark Pasnik, Michael Kubo, and Chris Grimley, authors of "Heroic: Concrete Architecture and the New Boston," will discuss how politics influenced urban renewal in Boston during the 1960s. Following the presentation, Christopher Lydon, host of Open Source, will interview the authors and explore how politics is also influencing renewal today.  

Click here to register. 

"Heroic: Concrete Architecture and the New Boston" details how public investment in Boston catalyzed enormous growth, after decades of stagnation and corrupt leadership, and resulted in a generation of bold buildings influenced by concrete modernism. Today, when concrete buildings across the nation are in danger of insensitive renovation or demolition, "Heroic" presents the numerous and diverse civic, cultural and academic concrete structures that were implemented in Boston more than in any other major U.S. city. 

The event will be held at Boston City Hall, one of the concrete buildings that defined Boston during this period, just a week before the Government Center T station reopens and ushers in the start of another renewal. Last week, city officials announced that City Hall Plaza will undergo a 3-year revitalization project, which may include a Ferris wheel, a winter ice park and an urban beach. 

Don't miss your chance to explore Boston's past on the heels of its exciting future! The event is free and open to the public, but advanced registration is required.

Click here to register.
results.name: WBUR Presents: Concrete Architecture and the New Boston

results.description:
Schedule

6:00-7:00 Networking with PIZZA

6:00-6:45 Roundtables (also with PIZZA)

6:45-7:00 Community Announcements / Job Leads

7:00-7:10 Announcements

7:10-8:15 Featured Presentation

8:15-8:30 Questions and Answers

Featured Presentation

Nancy Van Schooenderwoert will show how Agile principles can lead you to practices that speed hardware development while raising quality. Hardware designers who've witnessed successful Agile software teams in action are asking "Can we get some of that?" What they don't realize is that fundamental keys to agility came directly from hardware work!

Nancy began her Agile practices in development work on hardware-software products, after 15+ years as an electronics-designer-turned-software-engineer. Other teams around the world have started to apply Agile and Lean concepts in their hardware development work.

This presentation will give examples of Agile hardware development from several industries, including safety-critical applications. They are not merely transplanting Agile software practices; these hardware engineers starting from the core concepts of Agile and Lean to build practices appropriate to the special constraints of hardware.

With the coming explosion of IoT-related products, it will be vital for hardware and software teams to work together smoothly in a genuinely Agile way.

About the Speaker

As an electronics designer doing a bit of software development for flight simulators, Nancy Van Schooenderwoert learned about "Design for Testability", standard interfaces, on-chip debugging resources, spiral product lifecycle, "Hardware - Software co-design" and so on. Moving to full time software development and team lead work, she had a team working in iterations, using "test first" development, team-based estimates, - essentially most of the practices that became XP - a couple years before the first Agile books were out.

As an independent Agile coach, Nancy has worked with software and hardware teams, as well as teams doing other non-software work such as research, sensor development, and operations. She has led Agile change initiatives beyond software development in safety-critical, highly regulated industries, and teaches modern Agile approaches like Mob Programming, Agile Hardware, and Lean development methods.

results.description:
BGN Fans,  


We're excited to bring you March's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by Move Rate 20 Games, WeWork, OpenView, Downeast Cider House, and Mighty Squirrel! 

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. To celebrate their Kickstarter, Move Rate 20 is giving away a "BUCKETLOAD OF GAMES" and our good friends at Openview Partners are giving away loads of swag and Amazon giftcards. WeWork has offered to match every donation so your $5 donation is going a lot further.

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGN10 and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

Our games include:

• Settlers of Catan

• Race to the Galaxy

• Dominion

• Marvel Legendary

• Succession

• Puerto Rico

• DiXit

• San Juan

• Indie Game Spotlight: Move Rate 20's: Master of Spies 


• Or bring your own! 

SPONSORS

East Coast Product is the fastest most efficient way to build the right digital product to get your startup to it's next milestone. We are a product accelerator specializing in growth stage startups, helping them through strategy and execution. 

OpenView is a venture capital firm with over $700 million in total capital under management that invests in expansion stage software companies. Founded in 2006 and headquartered in Boston, MA, OpenView provides its portfolio with value-add services through OpenView Labs. Programs range from recruiting to market research and marketing and sales strategy. For more information, visit openviewpartners.com

MoveRate20Games is a game company that started with just a group of life long gaming fans who decided to turn that love into an active participation in the gaming industry. They recently launched their first ever Kickstarter, for their incredibly awesome card game Master of Spies.

Bundled in each serving of Mighty Squirrel, you will find a few of our favorite things: friendship, sports, entrepreneurship, innovation, and fun. Beer after sports goes hand-in-hand, so we created Mighty Squirrel, which has 4 grams of protein. Call us crazy? Fine. But you have to taste the mighty to understand the squirrel.

WeWork is the community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 56 locations in 16 cities and 35,000 members! Book a tour at wework.com 


New England's Craft Cider. Locally grown. Freshly Pressed. Gluten-Free. Not from Concentrate.

results.description:
CALLING ALL New C&C Members!

                           Tonight is all about YOU

Bring your favorite game and show us how to play it or just come and meet some new people who share your same passion in game playing.

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford .  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play games.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: New Members Night in Medford

results.description:
EAT TO THRIVE:
10-week course to Life Long Healthy Habits Healthy Living
with Betsy Bragg

* Tuesdays, January 26 -March 29  6:00 – 9:30 pm

  Come be motivated to change your life!!

Where:  
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

Upcoming course information – apply today – space is limited
(online/phone[masked])  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org

When:  Tuesdays:  January 26 - March 29,  2016

Location: 
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

  Early Bird Special: Save $50 if registered by December 29

Fee includes 383-page manual, sprouting kits, DVDs to watch,
and a five-course health-promoting meal each week.

Eat to Thrive

Class Dates:  Tuesdays, January 26 – March 29, 2016, 6:00 – 9:30 pm

Info Session:  Tuesday, January 5, 2016, 6:30 – 8:30 pm

Location: 
Arlington Senior Center Mural Room
27 Maple Street, Arlington MA

EAT TO THRIVE COURSE OPTIONS/TRACKS AND PRICING

1. AUDIT: This is for students whose goal it is to gain exposure to the subject matter. Whether they have an illness or simply a thirst for knowledge of the subject matter, they will be permitted to attend, borrow DVDs and participate.  They will be required to prepare and contribute to the five course meal. However, there are no attendance or written/oral requirements.  Fee: $555

2. REPEATING AUDIT STUDENTS:  (returning graduates) Fee: $355

3. HEALTH EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: This track is for students whose goal it is to apply the knowledge from this course to a career path. Successful completion of this program will lead to an Optimum Health Solution (OHS) Certificate of Completion. Requirements for this course are attendance at 8 out of 10 classes; a passing grade on two take-home essay tests; and a presentation with hands-on learning for a group of at least 5 people (to be described more in detail on the website). Fee: $755 

4. REAL KIDS REAL FOOD HEALTH (RKRF) EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE:
This track is designed for teachers or students seeking a career path in teaching upper elementary to middle school-age children and want to gain expertise in the subject area of healthy foods. Students enrolled in this certificate program will have an additional 6 hours of one-on-one teacher training with master educator, Betsy Bragg; students will learn kid-tested recipes and techniques for teaching and presentation; students will have the opportunity to observe other master teachers, participate in a practicum, and design their own lesson plan. Successful completion of this program will lead to an OHS RKRF Certificate of Completion.  Betsy’s background includes 48 years of teaching Elementary through University levels, M.Ed Stanford and Harvard Universities, M.A. Boston University, licensed in Special Education Lesley University, licensed in English Second Language University of Massachusetts. Fee $800. Repeating students (graduates) Fee $600

5. Eat to Thrive Educator Training Certificate: This track is designed for repeating students who want to teach a section of the OHS Eat to Thrive Program. In addition to the 10-week program, students will be given an additional 6 of hands-on training in all aspects of the curriculum and administration. As OHS plans to expand its Eat to Thrive program to other locations in Massachusetts, paid teachers will be required to hold this certification.  Prerequisite: Students must have taken an Eat to Thrive course and hold the Health Educator Certificate.  Fee: $650
results.how_to_find_us: Upcoming course information: apply today; space is limited (online/phone 781-899-6664)  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org
results.name: Eat to Thrive: 10 Weeks to Life Long Healthy Habits and Healthy Living

results.description:
“Great Real Estate Ponzi Scheme”…..the government scam!

The federal government passes legislation and creates a crisis, then uses your tax dollars “solve” the problem.  Sound like a scam to you?  They’re at it again, doing much of the same thing.  Do you have any idea where the real estate market is headed or how housing policy affects your real estate investment business?  We’ll explain why you should care – it’s your money.

 John Agostinelli and Chris Michaud have been in real estate and allied businesses for more than 50 years combined.  Their experience includes banking, lending, working at the FDIC, land development, spec home building, flipping and selling hundreds of REO properties.  They’ve written about their knowledge and research on the real estate markets and what is currently driving them. 

You will learn:

·  The true causes of the last bubble and why it is important to you

·  How Government Housing policy and the Federal Reserve create volatility in the real estate market and how this creates opportunities

·  The Sham of the Dodd Frank Act (DFA) and how it will not prevent the next bubble

·  The true intent of the Consumer Protection Financial Bureau (CFPB)

·  About TARP and other government bailouts which help your business

·  How this all combines to help predict what will happen to the real estate markets in the near term!

results.description:
Location: WeWork Dugout (you will need to sign in at the front door)
https://www.wework.com/locations/boston/fort-point

Presenter: Rich Tarro, IBM Big Data Architect

Abstract:
Today's analytics applications must not only be capable of handling ever increasing types of data (Variety), they need to do it in near real time (Velocity). Exponentially increasing amounts of data (Volume) need to be processed to yield correct actions (Veracity). These new analytics applications must also be flexible in terms of deployment - employing a combination of cloud and on-premise resources as required to meet the needs of the business. This type of hybrid cloud, near real time analytic application requires streaming analytics capabilities, messaging systems and secure gateways to integrate cloud and on-premise systems. In this meetup, we'll walk through how to create such an application. Simulated sensor data will be pre-processed in a node.js cloud application, transported via TCP to an on-premise Apache Kafka messaging system over a secure gateway, and monitored and analyzed with a Spark Streaming application running on Hadoop. We will explore the various technology components used in this application as well as demonstrate how they integrate in an end-to-end application flow. We will also do a deep dive into the Spark Streaming application itself.

Agenda:
- Networking, pizza, soda and beer
- Overview presentation covering the underlying technology components
- Demo showing the various components of the application
- Discussion with Q&A
results.name: Hybrid solution analysis of streaming sensor data with Spark Streaming & Kafka

results.description:
One of the great aspects of our Knapsack group is that we are a multiracial group. We believe that important racial justice work can be done in mixed race spaces. With that being said, it can also be important to have racial affinity time as well. Sometimes you might be the only person of color in the room when people are talking about an incident in the news/media pertaining to someone of your racial background; all eyes turn to you as if you are the spokesperson. Or maybe you identify as white and have a question you might want to ask but don’t know if it will be perceived as ‘racist’ in a mixed space so you hold off. We want to grow as a group and in doing so, sometimes it is good to break up into groups and talk about how we can work towards shared liberation using our personal strengths, privilege, and experience.

Racial affinity groups give an opportunity to share knowledge and experience with people who may feel similar. It is also a way to celebrate the differences among our racial groups. One of the purposes of doing this within Knapsack is for people with some shared experience to have the opportunity to collectively reflect on those realities.

We will meet as a large group and do an activity before splitting into racial affinity groups to do another activity separately. We will follow this up and come together in the end for closing reflections. Depending on what our attendance looks like, we can have two groups (white and POC) or multiple groups by breaking down POC into different racial groups.
results.name: Racial Affinity Groups

results.description:
"In this striking literary debut, Carol Rifka Brunt unfolds a moving story of love, grief, and renewal as two lonely people become the unlikeliest of friends and find that sometimes you don’t know you’ve lost someone until you’ve found them.

1987. There’s only one person who has ever truly understood fourteen-year-old June Elbus, and that’s her uncle, the renowned painter Finn Weiss. Shy at school and distant from her older sister, June can only be herself in Finn’s company; he is her godfather, confidant, and best friend. So when he dies, far too young, of a mysterious illness her mother can barely speak about, June’s world is turned upside down. But Finn’s death brings a surprise acquaintance into June’s life - someone who will help her to heal and to question what she thinks she knows about Finn, her family, and even her own heart.


At Finn’s funeral, June notices a strange man lingering just beyond the crowd. A few days later, she receives a package in the mail. Inside is a beautiful teapot she recognizes from Finn’s apartment and a note from Toby, the stranger, asking for an opportunity to meet. As the two begin to spend time together, June realizes she’s not the only one who misses Finn, and if she can bring herself to trust this unexpected friend, he just might be the one she needs the most.


An emotionally charged coming-of-age novel, Tell the Wolves I’m Home is a tender story of love lost and found, an unforgettable portrait of the way compassion can make us whole again." 

via goodreads

Please support our host restaurant! Bar Lola has delicious drinks and tapas. Order at the bar and then join us in the back room.
results.name: Boston Readers - Tell the Wolves I'm Home by Carol Rifka Brunt

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

results.description:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/uxpa-boston-boston-ixda-articulating-design-decisions-a-discussion-with-author-tom-greever-tickets-22179817431

NOTE: Security will be checking IDs for this event. The name on your ID must match the name on your registration. If you find you cannot attend the event, please either change your RSVP so others can attend, or transfer your registration to a friend.

Articulating Design Decisions
Tom Greever, Author and UX Director at Bitovi 


Tom Greever will be joining us to discuss his new book Articulating Design Decisions published by O'Reilly Media. (You do not need to have read the book to participate.) Every designer has had to justify designs to non-designers, yet most lack the ability to explain themselves in a way that is compelling and fosters agreement. The ability to effectively articulate design decisions is critical to the success of a project, because the most articulate person often wins. This practical talk will include principles, tactics, and actionable methods for talking about designs with executives, developers, or other stakeholders who have influence over the project with the goal of winning them over and creating the best user experience.

Tom helps companies and organizations design better websites and apps. He is the UX Director at Bitovi, a front-end design and development consulting company, and has worked with both small startups and large corporations across many different industries. 

Agenda
6:30 - 7:00 PM – Networking and Refreshments
7:00 - 7:15 PM – Introductions
7:15 - 8:00 PM - Presentation
8:00 - 8:15 PM - Q&A 

Can't Attend?

Please login into Eventbrite to cancel your RSVP. 

Code of Conduct


By registering and attending any UXPA Boston event, you agree to follow our Code of Conduct. If you have any questions, please contact a Board Member.
Have questions about UXPA Boston & Boston IxDA: Articulating Design Decisions, A Discussion with Author Tom Greever? Contact UXPA Boston & Boston IxDA

results.description:
About the class: 

JavaScript is the world's most popular programming language for a reason -- it's the primary way to build interaction on the web. Learning JavaScript is a logical next step once you've learned HTML/CSS.

Many programming courses end up glossing over some of the tricky words -- 'variable', 'object', 'method' -- this course is especially designed for beginners new to programming concepts, so you'll learn to program with JavaScript. If those words are confusing to you now, no worries! You're exactly who we want to teach.

In this class, we will be covering: basic development concepts, writing our own JavaScript functions,browser events, web animation, and we will touch on the jQuery library. Students will exit this class with a good grasp of basic programming principles and the knowledge of how to manipulate HTML elements.

Schedule: 

4 Class sessions

• Tuesday, March 15th: 6:30-8:30

• Tuesday, March 22nd: 6:30-8:30

• Tuesday, March 29th: 6:30-8:30

• Tuesday, April 5th: 6:30-8:30

Your payment registers you for the entire series.


Prerequisites: 

We suggest having a working knowledge of HTML and CSS as a prerequisite for this course. This course is specifically for beginners and we highly advise experienced developers to not take this class. 

Note: All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct

Tech Requirements: 

• Your laptop. (Note: a netbook or tablet is NOT a substitute!)

• A modern browser such as Chrome or Firefox installed.

• A text editor. We recommend Sublime Text 3 (It's free and available for Mac/PC/Linux).

About the teacher:

Hello World! I'm Christina (:

I'm a senior software developer at Vistaprint, where I work on the front-end user design experience. In my free time you can usually find me at hackathons, or working on side projects. I really enjoy coding, learning and inventing.

JavaScript was one of the first programming languages I started coding in so that I could build websites. Nowadays I use it all the time, from web development at work, to IoT projects like coding a virtual assistant on the Amazon echo, to building native apps! JS is so versatile, and is a great entry level programming language. I love JavaScript, and I can't wait to share it with you! 

LOCATION

A huge thank you to StubHub for hosting this event! 

StubHub is located at:

53 State Street on 5th floor 

Boston, MA

View on Google Maps

Someone will be available to let you into the building when you arrive.


Financial Need

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer.


Interested in hosting classes? Email us at boston[at]girldevelopit.com!

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!
results.name: Intro to JavaScript

Brian will be going over two libraries he's been working on lately. The first is mail and RFC2822 compliant mail builder. The second is Courier an adapter-based mail delivery system that uses the mail library.

Building a robot dashboard with Phoenix and Elm - Jean-François Cloutier
Jean needed to see what's going on in the "society of mind" of hi Elixir-powered, Lego robot. He also wanted to learn Elm. So he built a dashboard using Phoenix and Elm. Jean will share what he learned about Elm signals, tasks and ports, and how to integrate them with Phoenix channels.

results.description:
We will be playing indoors at the Mansfield Sports Plex (31 Oxford Rd, Mansfield, MA).  They have both courts and a turf field.  We can use cleats, sneakers, or indoor soccer shoes on the turf field, but only sneakers/indoor soccer shoes on the courts.  


Come prepared to play on either surface because if we get too many for the turf, we'll have to split into two games (one on turf and the other on the courts).

Game should be on turf. 

Cost should be about $10 per person.

Also bring both a white and dark shirt to help split into teams.

We are joining another group of players, so there should be enough to play even if there aren't many RSVPs.

Thanks,


-Dave

The change in venue is to allow easier access for those traveling.
Can't wait to see everyone!
results.name: Apologetics and the Christian canon

results.description:
Articulating Design Decisions 

Tom Greever, Author and UX Director at Bitovi Tom Greever will be joining us to discuss his new book Articulating Design Decisions published by O'Reilly Media. (You do not need to have read the book to participate.) Every designer has had to justify designs to non-designers, yet most lack the ability to explain themselves in a way that is compelling and fosters agreement. The ability to effectively articulate design decisions is critical to the success of a project, because the most articulate person often wins. This practical talk will include principles, tactics, and actionable methods for talking about designs with executives, developers, or other stakeholders who have influence over the project with the goal of winning them over and creating the best user experience.

Tom helps companies and organizations design better websites and apps. He is the UX Director at Bitovi, a front-end design and development consulting company, and has worked with both small startups and large corporations across many different industries. 

Agenda

6:30 - 7:00 PM – Networking and Refreshments 

7:00 - 7:15 PM – Introductions 

7:15 - 8:00 PM - Presentation 

8:00 - 8:15 PM - Q&A

RSVP on Eventbrite
results.name: UXPA/BostonChi: Articulating Design Decisions

results.description: Gerry Abbey didn't plan on becoming a writer when he first set-off on his year-long adventure to rural Taiwan as a Fulbright English teacher. However, over time he began to collect page after page of journal entries, reflecting on his time traveling. Only after his return did he make a conscious decision to transform his writings into a cohesive and engaging travel memoir. Be sure to join Gerry for a relaxed and interactive conversation about his process while attendees will be welcome to share their own. This event is geared towards all those who write while traveling, from aspiring bloggers to published authors. The travel writers circle begins in HI-Boston's Community Room, where writing topics & prompts will guide the conversations. Following the circle, attendees are welcomed to attend HI-Boston's midweek mixer and discuss writing in a more traditional literary setting: a local bar and pub.

results.description:
This month we are joined by rescue medium and author Amy Major. What is a rescue medium and what do they do? How can we help spirits and should we? Join us and find out more about this fascinating profession. Amy Major is a trained Psychic, Medium, Rescue Medium, Healer, Teacher, Lecturer and Author. At a young age she learned she had the ability to communicate with her spiritual and animal guides. Throughout childhood she developed Astral Projection, as well as the ability to see auras and energy surrounding people. In her early 20's, Amy was told by her guides that she was able to communicate with spirits. Amy has studied and worked at the New Millennium Psychic Center in Derry, NH for many years and became the lead medium in the Psychic Ghostbusters Team which conducted many spirit investigations/rescues. Amy is highly skilled in her psychic ability and provides psychic tarot card readings and mediumship readings at local Spirit/Psychic fairs.
She is an active member of a Spiritualist Church, The Church of Spiritual Life in Derry, NH, where she has been a member for over 12 years. She routinely provides mediumship readings and gallery readings at the church.
Amy is a lead Rescue Medium on many spirit investigations and rescues. She conducts workshops and lectures on Spirit Rescue in her area. Amy's book "Toward the Light, Rescuing Spirits, Trapped Souls and Earthbound Ghosts, explain Rescue Mediumship and Spirit Rescue techniques used to help earthbound spirits "cross over".
results.name: NEGP Paranormal Sudy Group - Rescue Medium

group.name: New England Ghost Project's Paranormal Study Group

ideas for viable moneymaking startups,

methods of collaboration, networking, forming teams & partnerships etc.

Boston Greenfest & Gov't opportunities.

Seminars - We will have seminars by Sustainable Energy engineers and other tech experts as often as possible.

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 3/15  Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston
